/au-victoria/aca/1985/s1.title: Short title
/au-victoria/aca/1985/s1.content:
This Act may be cited as the Accident 
Compensation Act 1985.

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s2/1.content: Subject to this section, this Act shall be deemed to have come into operation on the appointed day. Pt 1 Div. 1 (Heading) inserted by No. 80/2010 s. 15.

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s2/2.content: Part VII shall come into operation on the day Accident Compensation Act 1985 No. 10191 of 1985 2 fixed by proclamation of the Governor in Council published in the Government Gazette.

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s2/3.content: Section 91 shall come into operation on a day to be fixed by proclamation of the Governor in Council published in the Government Gazette.

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s2/4.content: Section 264(4) shall be deemed to have come into operation on 30 June 1985.

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s2/5.content: Parts I, II and VI and sections 272 and 275 come into operation on the day on which this Act receives the Royal Assent.

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s2/6.content: The item in Schedule Two which amends section 95 of the Stamps Act 1958 shall be deemed to have come into operation on 1 January 1985.

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s2/7.content: The item in Schedule Two which amends section 97 of the Stamps Act 1958 shall be deemed to have come into operation on 1 August 1985.

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s2/8.content: The items in Schedule Two which amend sections 98 and 99 of the Stamps Act 1958 shall be deemed to have come into operation on 30 June 1985.

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s3.title: Objects of Act
/au-victoria/aca/1985/s3.content:
Accident Compensation Act 1985 
No. 10191 of 1985 
3   
 (c) to increase the provision of suitable 
employment to workers who are injured to 
enable their early return to work; 
 (ca) to ensure the accident compensation scheme 
operates so that all claimants and users of the 
scheme are treated fairly, respectfully and 
with dignity;  
 (cb) to ensure the accident compensation scheme 
provides a high-quality service to all users of 
the scheme; 
 (d) to ensure appropriate compensation and 
provisional payments under this Act is paid 
to injured workers in the most socially and 
economically appropriate manner, as 
expeditiously as possible; 
 (e) to ensure workers compensation costs are 
contained so as to minimise the burden on 
Victorian businesses; 
 (f) to establish incentives that are conducive to 
efficiency and discourage abuse; 
 (g) to enhance flexibility in the system and allow 
adaptation to the particular needs of 
disparate work situations; 
 (h) to establish and maintain a fully-funded 
scheme; 
 (i) in this context, to improve the health and 
safety of persons at work and reduce the 
social and economic costs to the Victorian 
community of accident compensation.

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s3/a.content: to reduce the incidence of accidents and The objects of this Act are— diseases in the workplace;

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s3/b.content: to make provision for the effective occupational rehabilitation of injured workers and their early return to work; amended by No. 83/1987 s. 4, substituted by No. 67/1992 s. 4. amended by No. 50/1994 s. 4.

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s3/c.content: to increase the provision of suitable Accident Compensation Act 1985 No. 10191 of 1985 3 employment to workers who are injured to enable their early return to work;

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s3/ca.content: to ensure the accident compensation scheme operates so that all claimants and users of the scheme are treated fairly, respectfully and with dignity;

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s3/cb.content: to ensure the accident compensation scheme provides a high-quality service to all users of the scheme;

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s3/d.content: to ensure appropriate compensation and provisional payments under this Act is paid to injured workers in the most socially and economically appropriate manner, as expeditiously as possible;

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s3/e.content: to ensure workers compensation costs are contained so as to minimise the burden on Victorian businesses;

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s3/f.content: to establish incentives that are conducive to efficiency and discourage abuse;

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s3/g.content: to enhance flexibility in the system and allow adaptation to the particular needs of disparate work situations;

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s3/h.content: to establish and maintain a fully-funded scheme; (i) in this context, to improve the health and safety of persons at work and reduce the social and economic costs to the Victorian community of accident compensation.

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s4.title: Application of Act
/au-victoria/aca/1985/s4.content:
Accident Compensation Act 1985 
No. 10191 of 1985 
5   
 (3) Nothing in this Act entitles a worker to 
compensation in respect of a disease due to the 
nature of any employment in which the worker 
was employed unless the worker has been 
employed in employment of that nature on or after 
the appointed day but before 1 July 2014. 
 (4) On and after 1 July 2014, a claim for 
compensation under this Act must be given, 
served or lodged in accordance with section 20 
of the Workplace Injury Rehabilitation and 
Compensation Act 2013. 
 (5) This Act must be read and construed as one with 
the Workplace Injury Rehabilitation and 
Compensation Act 2013.

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s4/1.content: Despite anything to the contrary in this Act—

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s4/1/a.content: this Act, other than Divisions 6A and 6B of Part IV, applies to and in relation to an injury to a worker on or after the appointed day but before 1 July 2014 arising out of or in the course of employment on or after the appointed day; and

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s4/1/b.content: this Act, other than Divisions 6A and 6B of Part IV, does not apply to or in relation to an injury to a worker— (i) before the appointed day arising out of or in the course of employment before the appointed day; or (ii) after the appointed day arising out of or in the course of employment solely before the appointed day; and

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s4/1/c.content: Divisions 6A and 6B of Part IV apply in relation to an injury, disease or industrial deafness caused to or suffered by a worker before, on or after the appointed day which has arisen out of or in the course of any employment or is due to the nature of any employment in which the worker was employed at any time.

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s4/2.content: Subsection (1) does not affect the application of Part I or III where it is necessary for those Parts to apply to or in respect of an injury to a worker before the appointed day arising out of or in the course of employment. amended by No. 48/1986 s. 3, substituted by No. 83/1987 s. 5. amended by Nos 13/1988 s. 7(a), 67/2013 s. 624(2). amended by No. 13/1988 s. 7(a). amended by Nos 13/1988 s. 7(a), 18/1991 s. 12(1)(a).

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s4/3.content: Nothing in this Act entitles a worker to Accident Compensation Act 1985 No. 10191 of 1985 5 compensation in respect of a disease due to the nature of any employment in which the worker was employed unless the worker has been employed in employment of that nature on or after the appointed day but before 1 July 2014.

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s4/4.content: On and after 1 July 2014, a claim for compensation under this Act must be given, served or lodged in accordance with section 20 of the Workplace Injury Rehabilitation and Compensation Act 2013.

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s4/5.content: This Act must be read and construed as one with the Workplace Injury Rehabilitation and Compensation Act 2013.

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s5/1.content: In this Act— appointed day means four o'clock in the afternoon of the day before the proclaimed day; first entitlement period has the meaning given by section 91E; personal and household service means the provision of one or more of the following of a kind or type, and by a person, approved by the Authority—

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s5A.title: Definition—pre-injury average weekly earnings
/au-victoria/aca/1985/s5A.content:
Accident Compensation Act 1985 
No. 10191 of 1985 
12   
 (7) In relation to a worker to whom section 6 or 8 
applies, the worker's pre-injury average weekly 
earnings must be calculated with reference to the 
amounts payable to the contractor and deemed to 
be remuneration under that section, expressed as a 
weekly sum.

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s5A/1.content: In this Act, pre-injury average weekly earnings, in respect of a relevant period in relation to a worker, means, subject to this section, the sum of—

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s5A/1/a.content: the average of the worker's ordinary earnings during the relevant period (excluding from that period any week during which the worker did not actually work and— (i) was not on paid leave; or (ii) was on paid leave at a rate less than the base rate of pay)— expressed as a weekly sum; and

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s5A/1/b.content: the worker's earnings enhancement (if any) in the relevant enhancement period. Pt 1 Div. 2 (Heading) inserted by No. 80/2010 s. 21. inserted by No. 64/1989 s. 6, amended by Nos 50/1994 s. 8, 7/1996 s. 49(a), 107/1997 ss 8(3), 30(2)–(4), 26/2000 s. 4(1)(2), 95/2003 s. 5, 102/2004 s. 38(1)(a)(b), 41/2006 s. 3, 60/2007 s. 24, 9/2010 ss 4–8, substituted by No. 80/2010 s. 21. substituted by No. 67/2013 s. 626(2) (as amended by No. 44/2014 s. 24(26)). amended by No. 44/2014 s. 26.

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s5A/2.content: If a worker has been continuously employed by Accident Compensation Act 1985 No. 10191 of 1985 10 the same employer for less than 4 weeks before the injury, pre-injury average weekly earnings, in relation to that worker, may be calculated having regard to—

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s5A/2/a.content: the average of the worker's ordinary earnings that the worker could reasonably have been expected to have earned in that employment, but for the injury, during the period of 52 weeks after the injury expressed as a weekly sum; and

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s5A/2/b.content: the worker's earnings enhancement (if any) in the relevant enhancement period.

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s5A/3/a.content: was not a full time worker immediately before the injury; and

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s5A/3/b.content: at the time of the injury was seeking full time employment; and

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s5A/3/c.content: had been predominantly a full time worker during the period of 78 weeks immediately before the injury— pre-injury average weekly earnings, in relation to that worker, means the sum of—

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s5A/3/d.content: the average of the worker's ordinary earnings while employed during the period of 78 weeks immediately before the injury (excluding from that period any week during which the worker did not actually work and— (i) was on unpaid leave; or substituted by No. 67/2013 s. 626(3) (as amended by No. 44/2014 s. 24(26)).

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s5A/e.content: the worker's earnings enhancement (if any) Accident Compensation Act 1985 No. 10191 of 1985 11 (ii) was on paid leave at a rate less than the base rate of pay)— whether or not the employer is the same employer as at the time of the injury, expressed as a weekly sum; and in the relevant enhancement period.

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s5A/4.content: If a worker is a person engaged by an employer to participate as a contestant in a sporting or athletic activity within the meaning of section 16(1) and the injury is not received while the person is—

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s5A/4/a.content: participating, or training for or preparing to participate, as a contestant in a sporting or athletic activity; or

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s5A/4/b.content: travelling between a place of residence and a place where the activity, training or preparation is held— any remuneration paid or payable in respect of such participation, training, preparation or travel is not to be taken into account in calculating the worker's pre-injury average weekly earnings.

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s5A/5.content: In relation to a worker of a class referred to in column 2 of an item in Schedule 1A, pre-injury average weekly earnings means the amount determined in accordance with column 3 of that item, expressed as a weekly sum.

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s5A/6.content: In relation to a worker to whom section 7 or 7A applies, the worker's pre-injury average weekly earnings must be calculated with reference to the amounts payable to the worker and deemed to be remuneration under that section, expressed as a weekly sum.

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s5A/7.content: In relation to a worker to whom section 6 or 8 Accident Compensation Act 1985 No. 10191 of 1985 12 applies, the worker's pre-injury average weekly earnings must be calculated with reference to the amounts payable to the contractor and deemed to be remuneration under that section, expressed as a weekly sum.

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s5AA.title: Definitions applying to pre-injury average weekly

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s5AA/1.content: Subject to this section, a reference to the relevant earnings—relevant period period in relation to pre-injury average weekly earnings of a worker is a reference to—

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s5AA/1/a.content: in the case of a worker who has been continuously employed by the same employer for the period of 52 weeks immediately before the injury, that period of 52 weeks;

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s5AA/1/b.content: in the case of a worker who has been continuously employed by the same employer for less than 52 weeks immediately before the injury, the period of continuous employment by that employer.

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s5AA/2.content: Subject to subsection (4), the relevant period, in relation to pre-injury average weekly earnings of a worker who, during the 52 weeks immediately before the injury, voluntarily (otherwise than by reason of an incapacity for work resulting from, or materially contributed to by, an injury which entitles the worker to compensation under this Act)—

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s5AA/2/a.content: alters the ordinary hours of work; or

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s5AA/2/b.content: alters the nature of the work performed by the worker— and, as a result, the worker's ordinary earnings are reduced, does not include the period before the reduction takes effect. inserted by No. 80/2010 s. 21. amended by No. 35/2020 s. 54(1).

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s5AA/3.content: If, during the period of 52 weeks immediately Accident Compensation Act 1985 No. 10191 of 1985 13 before the injury, a worker—

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s5AA/3/b.content: is appointed to a different position— (otherwise than on a temporary basis) and, as a result, the worker's ordinary earnings are increased, the relevant period in relation to the worker begins on the day on which the promotion or appointment takes effect.

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s5AA/4.content: If the relevant period, in relation to the pre-injury average weekly earnings of a worker during the 52 weeks immediately before the worker's injury would otherwise include a period of time during the prescribed period and the worker's earnings during the period occurring in the prescribed period are reduced for a COVID-19 reason, the relevant period in relation to the worker does not include the period occurring in the prescribed period.

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s5AA/5.content: In this section— COVID-19 reason means, in relation to the reduction of earnings of a worker, that the reduction is a consequence of one or more of the following occurring during the prescribed period because of the COVID-19 pandemic—

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s5AA/5/a.content: the ordinary hours of work of the worker are reduced;

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s5AA/5/b.content: the nature of the work performed by the worker is altered;

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s5AA/5/c.content: the earnings of the worker are reduced; prescribed period means the period starting on 1 March 2020 and ending on 31 December 2020. inserted by No. 35/2020 s. 54(2). inserted by No. 35/2020 s. 54(2).

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s5AB.title: Definitions applying to pre-injury average weekly

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s5AB/1.content: Subject to this section, in relation to pre-injury earnings—ordinary earnings average weekly earnings, the ordinary earnings of a worker in relation to a week during the relevant period are—

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s5AB/1/a.content: if the worker's base rate of pay is calculated on the basis of ordinary hours worked, the sum of— (i) the worker's earnings calculated at that rate for ordinary hours in that week during which the worker worked or was on paid leave at the base rate of pay; and (ii) if the worker receives a piece rate payment or a commission or both a piece rate payment and a commission, the amount of piece rate payments and commissions the worker receives in respect of that week; or

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s5AB/1/b.content: if paragraph (a) does not apply, the actual earnings (other than an amount of a kind referred to in section 5AC(1)(a), (b), (c), (e) or (f)) paid or payable to the worker in respect of that week— and include—

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s5AB/1/c.content: any other amount (other than an amount of a kind referred to in section 5AC(1)(a), (b), (c), (e) or (f)) for the performance of work by the worker, that, under the worker's terms of employment, the employer is required to apply or deal with on behalf of the worker in accordance with the worker's instructions, in respect of that week; and inserted by No. 80/2010 s. 21. substituted by No. 67/2013 s. 626(4) (as amended by No. 44/2014 s. 24(26)).

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s5AB/d.content: the monetary value of— Accident Compensation Act 1985 No. 10191 of 1985 15 (i) residential accommodation; and (ii) use of a motor vehicle; and (iii) health insurance; and (iv) education fees— provided in respect of that week to the worker by the employer for the performance of work by the worker (non-pecuniary benefit).

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s5AB/2.content: For the purposes of subsection (1)(d), the monetary value of a non-pecuniary benefit is—

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s5AB/2/a.content: the value that would be the value as a fringe benefit for the purposes of the Fringe Benefits Tax Assessment Act 1986 of the Commonwealth, calculated in accordance with section 5C of this Act, divided by 52; or

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s5AB/2/b.content: in the case of residential accommodation that is not a fringe benefit or is otherwise not subject to fringe benefits tax, the amount that would reasonably be payable for that accommodation, or equivalent accommodation in the same area, in respect of that week if it were let on commercial terms.

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s5AB/3.content: A reference to ordinary earnings does not include, and is deemed never to have included, a reference to any employer superannuation contribution.

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s5AC.title: Definition applying to pre-injury average weekly

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s5AC/1.content: In relation to pre-injury average weekly earnings earnings and current weekly earnings—base rate of pay and current weekly earnings, a reference to a base rate of pay is a reference to the rate of pay payable to a worker for his or her ordinary hours of work but does not include—

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s5AC/1/f.content: any separately identifiable amount not referred to in paragraphs (a) to (e).

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s5AC/2.content: In relation to pre-injury average weekly earnings and current weekly earnings, if, at the time of the injury—

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s5AC/2/a.content: a worker's base rate of pay is prescribed by an industrial award that applies to the worker; and

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s5AC/2/b.content: the worker's actual rate of pay for ordinary hours is higher than that rate of pay— the worker's actual rate of pay is to be taken to be the worker's base rate of pay. inserted by No. 80/2010 s. 21.

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s5B/a.content: if the worker's base rate of pay is calculated In this Act, current weekly earnings of a worker in relation to a week means— on the basis of ordinary hours worked, the sum of— (i) the worker's earnings so calculated for the ordinary hours worked during that week; and (ii) amounts paid or payable for overtime or shift allowances in respect of that week; and (iii) amounts paid or payable as piece rates or commissions in respect of that week; or

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s5B/b.content: if paragraph (a) does not apply, the worker's actual earnings (other than an amount of a kind referred to in section 5AC(1)(a), (b), (c) or (f)) in respect of that week. * * * * * substituted by No. 67/2013 s. 626(6) (as amended by No. 44/2014 s. 24(26)). inserted by No. 64/1989 s. 6, amended by No. 67/1992 s. 8, substituted by No. 80/2010 s. 22. inserted by No. 50/1994 s. 7, substituted by No. 9/2010 s. 95, repealed by No. 67/2013 s. 627(1).

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s80.title: Entitlement to compensation only if employment
/au-victoria/aca/1985/s80.content:
Accident Compensation Act 1985 
No. 10191 of 1985 
24   
 (b) an air-cushion vehicle, or other similar 
craft— 
used wholly or primarily in navigation by 
water; 
State includes— 
 (a) Territory; and 
 (b) the offshore area, within the meaning 
of the Offshore Petroleum and 
Greenhouse Gas Storage Act 2006 of 
the Commonwealth, of the relevant 
State or Territory.

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s80/1.content: There is no entitlement to compensation under this connected with Victoria Act other than in respect of employment that is connected with this State.

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s80/2.content: The fact that a worker is outside this State when the injury happens does not prevent an entitlement to compensation arising under this Act in respect of employment that is connected with this State.

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s80/3.content: A worker's employment is connected with—

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s80/3/a.content: the State in which the worker usually works in that employment; or

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s80/3/b.content: if no State or no one State is identified by paragraph (a), the State in which the worker is usually based for the purposes of that employment; or

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s80/3/c.content: if no State or no one State is identified by paragraph (a) or (b), the State in which the employer's principal place of business in Australia is located.

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s80/4.content: In the case of a worker working on a ship, if no State or no one State is identified by subsection (3), a worker's employment is, while working on a ship, connected with the State in which the ship is registered or (if the ship is registered in more than one State) the State in which the ship most recently became registered.

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s80/5.content: If no State is identified by subsection (3) or (if applicable) (4), a worker's employment is connected with this State if— New s. 80 inserted by No. 95/2003 s. 15.

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s80/b.content: the offshore area, within the meaning of the Offshore Petroleum and Greenhouse Gas Storage Act 2006 of the Commonwealth, of the relevant State or Territory.

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s80/6.content: In deciding whether a worker usually works in a State, regard must be had to the worker's work history with the employer over the preceding 12 months and the intentions of the worker and employer. However, regard must not be had to any temporary arrangement under which the worker works in a State for a period of not longer than 6 months.

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s80/7.content: Subject to subsection (6), in determining whether a worker usually works in a State or is usually based in a State for the purposes of employment, regard must be had to any period during which a worker works in a State or is in a State for the purposes of employment whether or not under the statutory workers compensation scheme of that State the person is regarded as a worker or as working or employed in that State.

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s80/8.content: Compensation under this Act does not apply in respect of the employment of a worker on a ship if the Seafarers Rehabilitation and Compensation Act 1992 of the Commonwealth applies to the worker's employment.

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s80/9.content: In this section— ship means any kind of vessel used in navigation by water, however propelled or moved, and includes—

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s80/9/a.content: a barge, lighter, or other floating vessel; and

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s81.title: Application to sailors
/au-victoria/aca/1985/s81.content:
Accident Compensation Act 1985 
No. 10191 of 1985 
26   
 (b) a duplicate agreement or list of the crew 
of a ship lost with all hands made out and 
produced by the proper officer out of official 
custody shall in the absence of proof to the 
contrary be sufficient evidence that the 
sailors named were on board at the time the 
ship was lost.

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s81/1.content: In this section— port includes place or harbour; sailor means any person working in any capacity on board a ship; ship has the same meaning as in section 80. * * * * *

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s81/2.content: This Act applies with the following modifications in respect of an injury that happens on a ship to a sailor working on the ship where the sailor's employment is connected with Victoria—

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s81/2/a.content: except where the sailor is the master, the notice of injury and the claim for compensation may be served on the master of the ship as if the master were the employer; State substituted by No. 80/2010 s. 46(1). sailor amended by No. 95/2003 s. 16(1)(a). ship substituted by No. 95/2003 s. 16(1)(b). Victorian ship repealed by No. 95/2003 s. 16(1)(c). amended by Nos 83/1987 s. 35, 95/2003 s. 16(2).

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s81/b.content: a duplicate agreement or list of the crew Accident Compensation Act 1985 No. 10191 of 1985 26 of a ship lost with all hands made out and produced by the proper officer out of official custody shall in the absence of proof to the contrary be sufficient evidence that the sailors named were on board at the time the ship was lost.

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s81/c.content: a claim for compensation in respect of the death of a sailor shall be made within six months after notice of the death has been received by the claimant;

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s81/d.content: if a ship is lost with all hands a claim for compensation in respect of the death of a sailor shall be made within 18 months after the date on which the ship is deemed under subsection (3) to have been lost with all hands;

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s81/e.content: if a sailor dies without leaving any dependants compensation shall not be payable if the owner or charterer of the ship is liable to pay the expenses of burial or cremation under any Act in force in Victoria;

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s81/f.content: weekly payments shall not be payable for any period during which the owner or charterer of the ship is liable to pay the expenses of maintenance of any injured sailor;

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s81/g.content: notwithstanding any limitation of liability in any other law, compensation shall be paid in full.

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s81/3.content: Without prejudice to any other means of proof available—

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s81/3/a.content: a ship shall be deemed to have been lost with all hands on board if it is shown by an official return produced out of official custody or other evidence that the ship left a port of departure at least 12 months before the institution of proceedings under this Act and has not been heard of since that departure; and

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s82.title: Entitlement to compensation
/au-victoria/aca/1985/s82.content:
Accident Compensation Act 1985 
No. 10191 of 1985 
32   
 (f) an injury that results in permanent

 (g) a brachial plexus injury that results in

of a limb;

a significant permanent inability to 
undertake the necessary activities of 
daily living.

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s82/1.content: If there is caused to a worker an injury arising out of or in the course of any employment, the worker shall be entitled to compensation in accordance with this Act.

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s82/2.content: If there is caused to a worker an injury arising out of or in the course of any employment which results in or materially contributes to the death of the worker, the worker's dependants shall be entitled, subject to this Act, to compensation in accordance with this Act. Note Subsections (1) and (2), as amended by sections 3(3) and 3(4) of the Accident Compensation and Transport Accident Acts (Amendment) Act 2003, only apply to injuries that occur on or after the date of commencement of section 3 of that Act—see section 262. (2A) There is no entitlement to compensation in respect of an injury to a worker if the injury is a mental injury caused wholly or predominantly by any one or more of the following—

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s82/2/a.content: management action taken on reasonable grounds and in a reasonable manner by or on behalf of the worker's employer; or

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s82/2/b.content: a decision of the worker's employer, on reasonable grounds, to take, or not to take any management action; or amended by Nos 67/1992 s. 11(1), 95/2003 s. 3(3). amended by Nos 67/1992 s. 11(1), 107/1997 s. 22, 95/2003 s. 3(4)(a)(b). Note to s. 82(2) inserted by No. 95/2003 s. 3(4)(c). inserted by No. 67/1992 s. 11(2), substituted by No. 9/2010 s. 12.

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s82/d.content: amputation of a limb, hand or foot;

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s82/a.content: a significant acquired permanent brain injury;

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s82/3.content: If it is proved that an injury to a worker Accident Compensation Act 1985 No. 10191 of 1985 28 (whether or not intended to be inflicted) was deliberately or wilfully self-inflicted, there is no entitlement to compensation in respect of that injury.

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s82/4.content: Subject to sections 82A, 82B, 82BA and 82C, if it is proved that an injury to a worker is attributable to the worker's serious and wilful misconduct (including, but not limited to, being under the influence of intoxicating liquor or a drug or both), there is no entitlement to compensation in respect of that injury. * * * * *

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s82/5.content: Subsection (4) shall not apply if the injury results in death or severe injury.

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s82/6.content: Subject to subsections (2B) and (2C), if a worker suffers an injury which occurs by way of a gradual process over time and which is due to the nature of employment in which the worker was employed at any time before notice of the injury was given, the worker or the worker's dependants shall be entitled to compensation under this Act as if the injury were an injury arising out of or in the course of employment. substituted by No. 64/1989 s. 9(1), amended by No. 9/2010 s. 13(2). amended by No. 64/1989 s. 9(2), substituted by No. 9/2010 s. 13(3), amended by No. 49/2014 s. 49. inserted by No. 83/1987 s. 36, amended by Nos 64/1989 s. 37(1)(b), 94/2003 s. 40, 93/2009 s. 49(5), repealed by No. 9/2010 s. 13(3). amended by No. 9/2010 s. 13(4). amended by Nos 67/1992 s. 11(3), 95/2003 s. 3(6)(a)(b).

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s82/7.content: If it is proved that before commencing Accident Compensation Act 1985 No. 10191 of 1985 29 employment with the employer—

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s82/7/a.content: a worker had a pre-existing injury or disease of which the worker was aware; and

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s82/7/b.content: the employer in writing— (i) advised the worker as to the nature of the proposed employment; and (ii) requested the worker to disclose all pre-existing injuries and diseases suffered by the worker of which the worker was aware and could reasonably be expected to foresee could be affected by the nature of the proposed employment; and (iii) advised the worker that subsection (8) will apply to a failure to make such a disclosure or the making of a false or misleading disclosure; and (iv) advised the worker as to the effect of subsection (8) on the worker's entitlement to compensation; and

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s82/7/c.content: the worker failed to make such a disclosure or made a false or misleading disclosure— subsection (8) applies.

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s82/8.content: If this subsection applies, any recurrence, aggravation, acceleration, exacerbation or deterioration of the pre-existing injury or disease arising out of or in the course of or due to the nature of employment with the employer does not entitle the worker to compensation under this Act.

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s82/9.content: If this section operates to prevent a worker or the worker's dependants recovering compensation in respect of an injury, the worker or the worker's dependants cannot rely on this section to claim to be entitled to take any other action or proceedings inserted by No. 107/1997 s. 23. inserted by No. 107/1997 s. 23. inserted by No. 107/1997 s. 23.

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s82/10.content: In this section— Accident Compensation Act 1985 No. 10191 of 1985 30 in respect of the injury whether under this Act or otherwise. management action, in relation to a worker, includes, but is not limited to, any one or more of the following—

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s82/10/c.content: suspension or stand-down of the worker's employment;

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s82/10/d.content: disciplinary action taken in respect of the worker's employment;

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s82/10/f.content: demotion, redeployment or retrenchment of the worker;

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s82/10/h.content: promotion of the worker; (i) reclassification of the worker's employment position;

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s82/10/j.content: provision of leave of absence to the worker;

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s82/10/k.content: provision to the worker of a benefit connected with the worker's employment;

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s82/10/l.content: training a worker in respect of the worker's employment;

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s82/10/m.content: investigation by the worker's employer of any alleged misconduct— (i) of the worker; or inserted by No. 9/2010 s. 14.

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s82/n.content: communication in connection with an Accident Compensation Act 1985 No. 10191 of 1985 31 (ii) of any other person relating to the employer's workforce in which the worker was involved or to which the worker was a witness; action mentioned in any of the above paragraphs; permanent blindness means—

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s82/e.content: full thickness burns that— (i) cause permanent severe disfigurement to the head or neck or an arm or a lower leg; or (ii) result in a significant permanent inability to undertake the necessary activities of daily living;

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s82/f.content: an injury that results in permanent Accident Compensation Act 1985 No. 10191 of 1985 32 blindness;

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s82/g.content: a brachial plexus injury that results in the permanent effective loss of the use of a limb;

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s82/h.content: a physical internal injury that results in a significant permanent inability to undertake the necessary activities of daily living.

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s82D/b.content: the conviction or finding is overturned on appeal— the Authority or self-insurer must pay to the worker, subject to and in accordance with this Act—

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s82D/c.content: the amount by which each weekly payment had been reduced, or the amount that had not been paid, together with interest at the prescribed rate on each such amount, in inserted by No. 49/2014 s. 51(3). inserted by No. 9/2010 s. 15. amended by No. 49/2014 s. 52. amended by No. 80/2010 s. 48(a).

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s82D/d.content: all amounts of compensation not paid in Accident Compensation Act 1985 No. 10191 of 1985 39 respect of the period from the date on which the payment was due until the date on which the amount is paid; and accordance with section 82C and to which, but for the conviction or finding of guilt, the worker would have been entitled.

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s83.title: Out of or in the course of employment
/au-victoria/aca/1985/s83.content:
Accident Compensation Act 1985 
No. 10191 of 1985 
41   
 (ii) acting without instructions from the 
employer— 
if the act was done by the worker for the 
purposes of and in connection with the 
employer's trade or business.

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s83/1.content: An injury to a worker is deemed to arise out of or in the course of employment for the purposes of section 82(1) and 82(2) if the injury occurs—

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s83/1/a.content: while the worker on any working day that the worker attended at the place of employment having been present at the place of employment is temporarily absent on that day during any authorised recess and does not during that absence voluntarily subject himself or herself to any abnormal risk of injury;

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s83/1/b.content: while the worker is, having regard to the nature of the worker's employment or any specific task which may require the worker to travel, travelling for the purposes of the worker's employment;

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s83/1/c.content: while the worker is in attendance at any school for the purposes of any trade, technical or other training which the worker is required to attend by the terms of his or her employment or as an apprentice or which the worker is expected to attend by the employer; and inserted by No. 80/2010 s. 48(b). amended by Nos 48/1986 s. 14, 64/1989 s. 35(b)(i)(ii)(c), substituted by No. 67/1992 s. 12. amended by No. 50/1994 s. 33(1). amended by No. 50/1994 s. 33(2).

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s83/d.content: while the worker is in attendance at any Accident Compensation Act 1985 No. 10191 of 1985 40 place for the purpose of obtaining a medical certificate, receiving medical, surgical or hospital advice, attention or treatment, receiving a personal and household service or an occupational rehabilitation service or receiving a payment of compensation in connection with any injury for which the worker is entitled to receive compensation or for the purpose of submitting to a medical examination required by or under this Act.

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s83/2.content: For the purposes of this section—

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s83/2/a.content: place of employment where there is no fixed place of employment includes the whole area, scope or ambit of employment;

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s83/2/b.content: travelling for the purposes of a worker's employment does not include travelling to and from the worker's place of employment or the places referred to in subsections (1)(c) and (1)(d);

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s83/2/c.content: an injury incurred while travelling for the purposes of a worker's employment is deemed not to have arisen out of or in the course of any employment if the injury occurred during or after any substantial interruption of or substantial deviation from the worker's journey made for a reason unconnected with his or her employment;

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s83/2/d.content: an injury is deemed to arise out of or in the course of employment even though at the time that the injury happened the worker was— (i) acting in contravention of any regulation (whether by or under an Act or otherwise) applicable to the work; or amended by No. 50/1993 s. 81(d). amended by No. 50/1994 s. 33(3).

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s84.title: Compensation for workers injured outside Victoria
/au-victoria/aca/1985/s84.content:
Accident Compensation Act 1985 
No. 10191 of 1985 
42   
 (3) For the purposes of this Act a worker who— 
 (a) is employed by the Crown, any 
administrative unit or any public statutory 
body constituted by or under the law of 
Victoria; and 
 (b) is directed by the Crown, administrative unit 
or public statutory body to work for or under 
the direction of any other person outside 
Victoria (whether within or outside 
Australia)— 
shall be deemed to continue to be employed by the 
Crown, administrative unit or public statutory 
body. 
 (4) This section does not apply in respect of an injury 
caused to or suffered by a worker outside 
Australia if the worker— 
 (a) has never resided in Australia; or 
 (b) had ceased to reside in Australia at the time 
the injury occurred.

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s84/1.content: Where an employer who resides or has a place of business in Victoria engages a worker in Victoria and an injury is caused to or suffered by the worker outside Australia in circumstances which had the injury occurred in Victoria would have entitled the worker or the worker's dependants to compensation—

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s84/1/b.content: in the case of the death of the worker, the worker's dependants— shall be entitled to compensation in accordance with this Act.

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s84/2.content: If an injury is caused to or suffered by a worker outside Australia who is employed by the Crown, any administrative unit or any public statutory body constituted by or under the law of Victoria in circumstances which had the injury occurred in Victoria would have entitled the worker or the worker's dependants to compensation—

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s84/2/b.content: in the case of the death of the worker, the worker's dependants— shall be entitled to compensation in accordance with this Act. amended by Nos 83/1987 s. 37(1)(a), 95/2003 s. 17(1). amended by Nos 83/1987 s. 37(1)(b), 95/2003 s. 17(1).

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s84/3.content: For the purposes of this Act a worker who— Accident Compensation Act 1985 No. 10191 of 1985 42

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s84/3/a.content: is employed by the Crown, any administrative unit or any public statutory body constituted by or under the law of Victoria; and

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s84/3/b.content: is directed by the Crown, administrative unit or public statutory body to work for or under the direction of any other person outside Victoria (whether within or outside Australia)— shall be deemed to continue to be employed by the Crown, administrative unit or public statutory body.

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s84/4.content: This section does not apply in respect of an injury caused to or suffered by a worker outside Australia if the worker—

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s84/4/a.content: has never resided in Australia; or

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s84/4/b.content: had ceased to reside in Australia at the time the injury occurred.

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s84B.title: Person not to be compensated twice
/au-victoria/aca/1985/s84B.content:
Accident Compensation Act 1985 
No. 10191 of 1985 
43   
 (3) The amount that is recoverable under 
subsection (2) is— 
 (a) the amount of compensation paid under this 
Act; or 
 (b) the amount of compensation received under 
the laws of the place other than this State— 
whichever is less.

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s84B/1.content: Compensation under this Act is not payable in respect of an injury to the extent that compensation has been received in respect of the same injury under the laws of a place other than this State (whether within or outside Australia).

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s84B/2.content: If a person receives compensation under this Act in respect of an injury and, in respect of the same injury, subsequently receives compensation under the laws of a place other than this State (whether within or outside Australia), the person from whom compensation under this Act is received may, in a court of competent jurisdiction, sue and recover from the person the amount described in subsection (3). amended by No. 95/2003 s. 17(2). inserted by No. 83/1987 s. 37(2), amended by No. 95/2003 s. 17(1). inserted by No. 95/2003 s. 18.

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s84B/3.content: The amount that is recoverable under Accident Compensation Act 1985 No. 10191 of 1985 43 subsection (2) is—

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s84B/3/a.content: the amount of compensation paid under this Act; or

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s84B/3/b.content: the amount of compensation received under the laws of the place other than this State— whichever is less.

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s85.title: Entitlement to damages outside Victoria
/au-victoria/aca/1985/s85.content:
Accident Compensation Act 1985 
No. 10191 of 1985 
46   
 (7) Any dispute under subsection (6) shall be 
determined by a court of competent jurisdiction. 
 (8) Unless a worker produces satisfactory evidence 
to the contrary, any amount recovered or to be 
recovered by a worker under the law of any 
place outside Victoria (whether within or outside 
Australia) as damages in respect of an injury shall 
be presumed to be damages for the same injury in 
respect of which the worker claims compensation 
or a right of action under this Act.

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s85/1.content: This section shall apply where an injury is caused to or suffered by a worker which gives the worker a right of action under the law of any place outside Victoria (whether within or outside Australia) in circumstances which would otherwise have entitled the worker or the worker's dependants to compensation under this Act.

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s85/2/a.content: damages has not been paid or recovered; and

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s85/2/b.content: judgment for damages has not been given or entered— in respect of the injury under the law of any place outside Victoria (whether within or outside Australia), the worker or in the case of the death of the worker the worker's dependants shall be entitled to compensation under this Act as if there (Heading) inserted by No. 95/2003 s. 19(1). amended by Nos 83/1987 s. 37(3), 95/2003 s. 19(2)(a)(b). amended by No. 95/2003 s. 19(3)(c)(d). amended by No. 95/2003 s. 19(3)(a). amended by No. 95/2003 s. 19(3)(b).

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s85/3.content: A person who has a right of action in respect of an Accident Compensation Act 1985 No. 10191 of 1985 44 were no right of action under the law of any place outside Victoria. injury under the law of any place outside Victoria (whether within or outside Australia) shall not be entitled to claim compensation in respect of the injury under this Act if in respect of the injury under the law of any place outside Victoria—

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s85/3/a.content: the person has been paid or recovered any amount of damages;

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s85/3/b.content: judgment for damages has been given or entered;

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s85/3/c.content: any payment into court has been accepted;

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s85/3/d.content: there has been a settlement or compromise of any claim; or

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s85/3/e.content: any action for damages is pending.

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s85/4/a.content: damages has been paid or recovered; or amended by No. 95/2003 s. 19(4)(a)(b). amended by No. 95/2003 s. 19(4)(c). substituted by No. 95/2003 s. 19(4)(d). amended by No. 95/2003 s. 19(4)(e). amended by No. 95/2003 s. 19(5)(c). amended by No. 95/2003 s. 19(5)(a).

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s85/b.content: judgment for damages has been given or Accident Compensation Act 1985 No. 10191 of 1985 45 entered— in respect of the injury under the law of any place outside Victoria (whether within or outside Australia) the worker or in the case of the death of the worker the worker's dependants shall not be entitled to compensation under this Act.

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s85/5.content: The worker or in the case of the death of the worker the worker's dependants shall not be entitled to compensation under this Act if a payment into court has been accepted by the worker or the worker's dependants in proceedings or a settlement or compromise of a claim has been made in respect of the injury under the law of any place outside Victoria (whether within or outside Australia).

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s85/6/a.content: receives compensation under this Act in respect of any injury; and

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s85/6/b.content: subsequently obtains damages or an award of damages, accepts a payment into court or settles or compromises a claim in respect of the injury under the law of any place outside Victoria (whether within or outside Australia)— the Authority, employer or a self-insurer shall be entitled to recover from that person the amount of compensation paid under this Act or an amount equal to the damages or payment obtained or made, settled or compromised whichever is the lesser amount. amended by No. 95/2003 s. 19(5)(b). amended by No. 95/2003 s. 19(6). amended by Nos 67/1992 s. 64(7)(a), 50/1993 s. 78(1)(h), 81/1998 s. 23(a), 95/2003 s. 19(7)(a). amended by No. 95/2003 s. 19(7)(a)(b).

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s85/7.content: Any dispute under subsection (6) shall be Accident Compensation Act 1985 No. 10191 of 1985 46 determined by a court of competent jurisdiction.

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s85/8.content: Unless a worker produces satisfactory evidence to the contrary, any amount recovered or to be recovered by a worker under the law of any place outside Victoria (whether within or outside Australia) as damages in respect of an injury shall be presumed to be damages for the same injury in respect of which the worker claims compensation or a right of action under this Act.

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s86.title: Compensation for disease due to employment
/au-victoria/aca/1985/s86.content:
Accident Compensation Act 1985 
No. 10191 of 1985 
47   
 (1A) For the purposes of subsection (1), a disease 
suffered by a worker is to be regarded as due to 
the nature of employment if, and only if, the 
nature of the employment gave rise to a 
significantly greater risk of the worker contracting 
the disease than had the worker not been 
employed in employment of that nature. 
 (2) Despite subsection (1), compensation is not 
payable in respect of a disease to the extent that 
the disease consists of, is caused by, results in or 
is associated with a heart attack injury or a stroke 
injury unless the worker's employment was a 
significant contributing factor to the disease or to 
the injury. 
Note 
This section in its current form only applies to injuries that occur 
on or after the date of commencement of section 3 of the Accident 
Compensation and Transport Accident Acts (Amendment) 
Act 2003—see section 263.

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s86/1/a.content: a worker suffers a disease that results in, or materially contributes to, the worker having either a current work capacity or no current work capacity; or

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s86/1/b.content: the death of a worker is caused, or materially contributed to, by a disease— and the disease is due to the nature of any employment in which the worker was employed at any time before notice of an injury relating to the disease is given under section 102, the worker or the worker's dependants are entitled to compensation under this Act as if the disease were an injury arising out of or in the course of employment. Note current work capacity is defined (section 5(1)) as a present inability arising from an injury such that the worker is not able to return to his or her pre-injury employment but is able to return to work in suitable employment. amended by No. 50/1994 s. 35(1). amended by No. 95/2003 s. 19(8)(a)(b). amended by Nos 67/1992 s. 13(1), 95/2003 s. 3(7)(a)–(c) (ILA s. 39B(1)). amended by No. 50/1994 s. 35(2) substituted by No. 80/2010 s. 49.

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s86/2.content: Despite subsection (1), compensation is not Accident Compensation Act 1985 No. 10191 of 1985 47 (1A) For the purposes of subsection (1), a disease suffered by a worker is to be regarded as due to the nature of employment if, and only if, the nature of the employment gave rise to a significantly greater risk of the worker contracting the disease than had the worker not been employed in employment of that nature. payable in respect of a disease to the extent that the disease consists of, is caused by, results in or is associated with a heart attack injury or a stroke injury unless the worker's employment was a significant contributing factor to the disease or to the injury. Note This section in its current form only applies to injuries that occur on or after the date of commencement of section 3 of the Accident Compensation and Transport Accident Acts (Amendment) Act 2003—see section 263.

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s87.title: Proclaimed diseases
/au-victoria/aca/1985/s87.content:
Accident Compensation Act 1985 
No. 10191 of 1985 
48   
 (b) has contracted a disease specified in relation 
to that place, process or occupation— 
then the disease shall be deemed to be due to the 
nature of the employment at such place or in such 
process or occupation unless the employer or the 
Authority or a self-insurer, as the case may be, 
proves to the contrary. 
 (3) A disease contracted by a worker shall be deemed 
to be a disease specified in a proclamation under 
subsection (1) in relation to a place, process or 
occupation if the Authority, self-insurer, a 
Conciliation Officer or the County Court (as the

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s87/1.content: The Governor in Council, after consultation by the Minister with the Authority, may by proclamation published in the Government Gazette from time to time proclaim diseases in relation to places, processes or occupations for the purpose of this section.

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s87/2.content: Without derogating from section 86, if at the time a claim was made a proclamation under subsection (1) was in force and—

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s87/2/a.content: the worker has been employed at any place or in any process or occupation proclaimed under subsection (1); and inserted by No. 80/2010 s. 49. inserted by No. 95/2003 s. 3(7)(c). amended by No. 67/1992 s. 64(7)(a). amended by Nos 67/1992 s. 64(7)(a), 50/1993 s. 78(1)(d), 81/1998 s. 23(b).

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s87/b.content: has contracted a disease specified in relation Accident Compensation Act 1985 No. 10191 of 1985 48 to that place, process or occupation— then the disease shall be deemed to be due to the nature of the employment at such place or in such process or occupation unless the employer or the Authority or a self-insurer, as the case may be, proves to the contrary.

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s87/3.content: A disease contracted by a worker shall be deemed to be a disease specified in a proclamation under subsection (1) in relation to a place, process or occupation if the Authority, self-insurer, a Conciliation Officer or the County Court (as the case requires) is satisfied that the disease contracted is substantially the same disease as the disease specified in the proclamation.

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s88/1.content: Industrial deafness or a proportion of industrial deafness which has occurred in circumstances which do not create any liability to pay compensation under this Act shall be excluded from the assessment of deafness for the purposes of calculating compensation under this section.

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s88/2.content: Compensation for industrial deafness shall be in accordance with this section and section 89 and Divisions 2, 2A and 2B. amended by Nos 64/1989 s. 35(d), 67/1992 s. 13(2), 50/1993 s. 78(1)(f), 81/1998 s. 23(a). amended by Nos 64/1989 s. 35(e)(i), 80/2010 s. 86(1), 67/2013 s. 628(1).

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s88/3.content: Unless the Authority, self-insurer, a Conciliation Accident Compensation Act 1985 No. 10191 of 1985 49 Officer, the Medical Panel or the County Court (as the case requires) determines otherwise industrial deafness shall be deemed to have occurred at a constant rate within the total number of years of exposure to industrial noise in employment.

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s88/4.content: Notwithstanding subsection (3) and subject to subsection (5), if a worker sustains industrial deafness, the injury is deemed to have been sustained by the worker on the last day on which the worker was—

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s88/4/b.content: exposed to conditions— by reason of which the injury was due to the nature of the worker's employment or arose out of or in the course of the worker's employment.

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s88/5.content: Notwithstanding subsection (3), if a worker sustains industrial deafness and on the day on which the worker gives, serves or lodges a claim for compensation in respect of the injury, the worker is still—

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s88/5/b.content: exposed to conditions— by reason of which the injury is due to the nature of the worker's employment or arises out of or in the course of employment, the injury is deemed to have been sustained on that day. amended by Nos 64/1989 s. 35(e)(ii), 67/1992 s. 13(3), 50/1993 s. 78(1)(f), 50/1994 s. 35(3), 81/1998 s. 23(a), 102/2004 s. 17(2). amended by No. 64/1989 s. 9(3) substituted by No. 80/2010 s. 86(2). inserted by No. 80/2010 s. 86(2).

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s89/1.content: In this section and sections 88, 91 and 98C— Compensation law means this Act, the Workers Compensation Act 1958 or any other workers compensation law of the Commonwealth or a State or Territory of the Commonwealth; further injury means a further loss of hearing in respect of industrial deafness after a worker has on one or more occasions suffered a prior injury; prior hearing loss means a loss of hearing for which a worker has received compensation under a Compensation law for loss of hearing; prior injury means industrial deafness for which the worker has received or become entitled to receive compensation for loss of hearing.

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s89/2.content: Subject to subsection (3A), a worker who suffers a further injury shall be entitled to receive in respect of the further injury, in addition to any other compensation payable under section 88, compensation in accordance with section 98C(3A), being compensation referrable to a percentage calculated in accordance with subsection (3) of the amount that would have been payable for a total loss of hearing. (Heading) inserted by No. 80/2010 s. 87(1). amended by No. 102/2004 s. 15(1). Compen- sation law inserted by No. 102/2004 s. 15(2). prior hearing loss inserted by No. 102/2004 s. 15(2). amended by No. 102/2004 s. 15(3)(a)(b).

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s89/3.content: The percentage shall be the difference between— Accident Compensation Act 1985 No. 10191 of 1985 51

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s89/3/a.content: the total percentage of the diminution of hearing in respect of industrial deafness from which the worker was suffering immediately after the further injury in respect of which the claim is made; and Note The percentage NAL loss is to be determined in accordance with section 91(4).  The percentage NAL loss is then converted in accordance with section 91(3).

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s89/3/b.content: the total percentage of the diminution of hearing in respect of industrial deafness immediately after the prior injury or prior hearing loss or in the case of more than one prior injury or prior hearing loss the latest of the prior injuries or prior hearing losses. Note The percentage NAL loss is to be determined in accordance with section 89(3C).  The percentage NAL loss is then converted in accordance with section 91(3A). (3A) Despite anything to the contrary in this Act, a worker who suffers a further injury is not entitled to compensation under this section or section 98C unless the worker has a diminution of hearing assessed as a binaural loss of hearing of at least 10 percent NAL resulting from the further injury and any prior injury or prior hearing loss. (3B) The total percentage referred to in subsection (3)(a) is to be determined in accordance with section 91(4). amended by Nos 102/2004 s. 15(4)(a), 80/2010 s. 87(2)(a). Note to s. 89(3)(a) inserted by No. 28/2005 s. 17(1). amended by Nos 102/2004 s. 15(4)(b), 80/2010 s. 87(2)(a). Note to s. 89(3)(b) inserted by No. 28/2005 s. 17(2). inserted by No. 102/2004 s. 15(5), amended by No. 80/2010 s. 87(2)(b). inserted by No. 102/2004 s. 15(5).

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s89/a.content: if a percentage has been determined in Accident Compensation Act 1985 No. 10191 of 1985 52 (3C) The total percentage referred to in subsection (3)(b) is to be determined by reference to— accordance with the Improved Procedure for Determination of Percentage Loss of Hearing (1988 Edition or a later prescribed edition) published by the National Acoustic Laboratory, that percentage; or

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s89/b.content: in any other case, the percentage which having regard to the medical evidence available is determined to be the equivalent of the percentage that (as nearly as can be estimated) would have been determined in accordance with the Improved Procedure for Determination of Percentage Loss of Hearing (1988 Edition or a later prescribed edition) published by the National Acoustic Laboratory. (3D) If a worker disputes the total percentage referred to in subsection (3)(b) as determined in accordance with subsection (3C), the Authority, self-insurer or a court must refer the question of what is the amount of the total percentage referred to in subsection (3)(b) as a medical question to a Medical Panel for an opinion.

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s89/4.content: For the purposes of this section the register kept under section 90 shall be taken into account. * * * * * inserted by No. 102/2004 s. 15(5). inserted by No. 102/2004 s. 15(5). inserted by No. 107/1997 s. 24, repealed by No. 102/2004 s. 15(6).

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s90.title: Effect of determination for industrial deafness
/au-victoria/aca/1985/s90.content:
(1) A determination for the payment of compensation 
for industrial deafness which is not reviewed 
shall be a final determination in respect of the 
percentage of the diminution of the worker's 
hearing on the date of the assessment. 
 (2) A determination for the payment of compensation 
shall state the percentage of diminution of the 
worker's hearing in respect of industrial deafness 
at the date of the determination in relation to 
which the amount of the compensation is 
assessed. 
 (3) A determination for compensation for industrial 
deafness shall fully extinguish all rights of the 
worker to compensation for industrial deafness 
under section 98, 98C or 98E or under the 
Workers Compensation Act 1958 up to the date 
of the determination but shall not prevent the 
worker from obtaining compensation under 
section 98, 98C or 98E for further industrial 
deafness suffered after that date. 
 (4) The Authority shall be advised of any 
determination for the payment of compensation 
for industrial deafness. 
 (5) The Authority shall keep a register of 
determinations for the payment of compensation 
for industrial deafness notified under 
subsection (4).

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s90/1.content: A determination for the payment of compensation for industrial deafness which is not reviewed shall be a final determination in respect of the percentage of the diminution of the worker's hearing on the date of the assessment.

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s90/2.content: A determination for the payment of compensation shall state the percentage of diminution of the worker's hearing in respect of industrial deafness at the date of the determination in relation to which the amount of the compensation is assessed.

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s90/3.content: A determination for compensation for industrial deafness shall fully extinguish all rights of the worker to compensation for industrial deafness under section 98, 98C or 98E or under the Workers Compensation Act 1958 up to the date of the determination but shall not prevent the worker from obtaining compensation under section 98, 98C or 98E for further industrial deafness suffered after that date.

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s90/4.content: The Authority shall be advised of any determination for the payment of compensation for industrial deafness.

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s90/5.content: The Authority shall keep a register of determinations for the payment of compensation for industrial deafness notified under subsection (4).

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s90A.title: Assessment of lung injury
/au-victoria/aca/1985/s90A.content:
Accident Compensation Act 1985 
No. 10191 of 1985 
54   
 (a) a serious lung injury; 
 (b) an injury that has been treated with lung 
transplant surgery.

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s90A/a.content: a serious lung injury; Accident Compensation Act 1985 No. 10191 of 1985 54

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s90A/b.content: an injury that has been treated with lung transplant surgery.

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s90B.title: Compensation for serious lung injury
/au-victoria/aca/1985/s90B.content:
(1) Despite section 104B(1A), the Authority or a self-
insurer may receive a claim for compensation 
under section 98C or 98E for a serious lung injury 
at any time after the date of the injury. 
 (2) For the purposes of subsection (1), the Authority 
or self-insurer, having regard to any relevant 
matter including medical evidence, must be 
satisfied that— 
 (a) the degree of impairment from the injury is 
unlikely to stabilise; and 
 (b) the injury requires treatment with lung 
transplant surgery.

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s90B/1.content: Despite section 104B(1A), the Authority or a self- insurer may receive a claim for compensation under section 98C or 98E for a serious lung injury at any time after the date of the injury.

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s90B/2.content: For the purposes of subsection (1), the Authority or self-insurer, having regard to any relevant matter including medical evidence, must be satisfied that—

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s90B/2/a.content: the degree of impairment from the injury is unlikely to stabilise; and

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s90B/2/b.content: the injury requires treatment with lung transplant surgery.

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s90C.title: Compensation for injury treated with lung

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s90C/1.content: Despite section 104B(1A), the Authority or a self- transplant surgery insurer may receive a claim for compensation under section 98C or 98E for an injury that has been treated with lung transplant surgery at any time after the date of the injury.

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s90C/2.content: For the purposes of a claim referred to in subsection (1), the degree of impairment of the worker is taken to be the greater of—

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s90C/2/a.content: the degree of impairment assessed in accordance with this Part; or

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s90C/3.content: For the purposes of subsections (1) and (2), the Authority or self-insurer, having regard to any relevant matter including medical evidence, must be satisfied that lung transplant surgery was required to treat the injury. inserted by No. 10/2022 s. 3. inserted by No. 10/2022 s. 3.

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s90D.title: Further impairment related to lung injury
/au-victoria/aca/1985/s90D.content:
(1) Despite section 104B(5AA), a worker who has 
received or become entitled to receive 
compensation under section 98C in respect of a 
serious lung injury may make a further claim for 
compensation under that section in respect of the 
injury after undergoing lung transplant surgery. 
 (2) Compensation referred to in subsection (1) is to be 
determined in accordance with section 98C(3B), 
being compensation referrable to a percentage 
which is the difference between— 
 (a) the degree of impairment suffered by the 
worker after undergoing lung transplant 
surgery; and 
 (b) the degree of impairment resulting from the 
worker's serious lung injury, as assessed for 
the purposes of the earlier claim.  
Note 
The deemed minimum level of impairment of a worker who 
has undergone lung transplant surgery is 30 per cent—see 
section 90C(2). 
 (3) Compensation payable in accordance with 
section 98C(3B) is payable in addition to any 
other compensation payable in accordance with 
this Act.

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s90D/1.content: Despite section 104B(5AA), a worker who has received or become entitled to receive compensation under section 98C in respect of a serious lung injury may make a further claim for compensation under that section in respect of the injury after undergoing lung transplant surgery.

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s90D/2.content: Compensation referred to in subsection (1) is to be determined in accordance with section 98C(3B), being compensation referrable to a percentage which is the difference between—

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s90D/2/a.content: the degree of impairment suffered by the worker after undergoing lung transplant surgery; and

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s90D/2/b.content: the degree of impairment resulting from the worker's serious lung injury, as assessed for the purposes of the earlier claim. Note The deemed minimum level of impairment of a worker who has undergone lung transplant surgery is 30 per cent—see section 90C(2).

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s90D/3.content: Compensation payable in accordance with section 98C(3B) is payable in addition to any other compensation payable in accordance with this Act.

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s91/7/b.content: if a worker presents for assessment in relation to injuries which occurred on different dates, the impairments are to be assessed chronologically by date of injury;

(7AA) For the purposes of section 98C(2A)(a)(ii) and (iii), assessments of spinal impairment are to specify the whole person values derived in accordance with section 3.3 of Chapter 3 of the A.M.A. Guides. (7A) For the purposes of Subdivision 1 of Division 3A and of section 134AB—

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s91/9.content: Despite anything to the contrary in the A.M.A Accident Compensation Act 1985 No. 10191 of 1985 63 * * * * * Guides, in determining a person's degree of impairment, no number determined under the A.M.A Guides is to be rounded up or down, regardless of whether the number represents an initial, an intermediate, a combined or a final value, unless the rounding is expressly required or permitted by this Act.

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s91/10.content: A number determined under the A.M.A Guides must be rounded to the nearest whole percent. Example A final degree of impairment of 95% must be rounded to 10%.  A final degree of impairment of 84% must be rounded to 8%. Note Section 264(1) sets out the transitional provisions that apply to subsections (9) and (10). /au-victoria/aca/1985/s91A.title: Determination of State with which worker's

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s91A/1.content: If the question of whether this State is connected employment is connected in proceedings under this Act with a worker's employment arises in proceedings in a court in relation to a claim for compensation under this Act or a request for provisional payments under Division 2BA, that court must—

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s91A/1/a.content: determine the State with which the worker's employment is connected in accordance with section 80; and

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s91A/1/b.content: cause that determination to be entered in the records of the court.

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s91A/2.content: Subsection (1) does not apply if there is a determination that is to be recognised under section 91C. inserted by No. 95/2003 s. 7, amended by No. 60/2007 s. 25(4). Pt 4 Div. 1A (Heading and ss 91A–91D) inserted by No. 95/2003 s. 20. inserted by No. 95/2003 s. 20. amended by No. 5/2021 s. 33.

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s91B.title: Determination by County Court of State with which
/au-victoria/aca/1985/s91B.content:
worker's employment is connected 
 (1) If a claim for compensation has been made under 
this Act or a request for provisional payments has 
been made under Division 2BA, a party to the 
claim or request may apply to the County Court 
for a determination of the question of which State 
is the State with which the worker's employment 
is connected. 
 (2) The County Court must determine an application 
under subsection (1) in accordance with section 80 
and cause that determination to be entered in the 
records of the court. 
 (3) An application under subsection (1) is not to be 
made or heard if there is a determination that is to 
be recognised under section 91C.

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s91B/1.content: If a claim for compensation has been made under worker's employment is connected this Act or a request for provisional payments has been made under Division 2BA, a party to the claim or request may apply to the County Court for a determination of the question of which State is the State with which the worker's employment is connected.

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s91B/2.content: The County Court must determine an application under subsection (1) in accordance with section 80 and cause that determination to be entered in the records of the court.

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s91B/3.content: An application under subsection (1) is not to be made or heard if there is a determination that is to be recognised under section 91C.

State includes Territory.

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s91C/1.content: If a determination of the State with which a worker's employment is connected has been made—

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s91C/1/a.content: by a court of this State under section 91A or 91B; or

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s91C/1/b.content: by a designated court under a provision of a law that corresponds with section 91A or 91B; or

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s91C/1/c.content: by a court of this State or another State in the course of proceedings on a claim for damages— the State so determined is to be recognised for the purposes of this Act as the State with which the worker's employment is connected. inserted by No. 95/2003 s. 20. amended by No. 5/2021 s. 34. inserted by No. 95/2003 s. 20.

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s91C/2.content: This section does not prevent any appeal relating Accident Compensation Act 1985 No. 10191 of 1985 66 to any such determination of a court. If the determination is altered on appeal, the altered determination is to be recognised under subsection (1).

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s91C/3.content: In this section— corresponding law means the provisions of the statutory workers compensation scheme of another State that corresponds with section 80; designated court means—

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s91C/3/a.content: the Supreme Court of a State in which a corresponding law is in force; or

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s91C/3/b.content: a court, tribunal or other decision- making body of a State in which a corresponding law is in force that is declared by the Minister to be a designated court for the purposes of this section by a notice published in the Government Gazette; State includes Territory.

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s91EA/1/a.content: a person is entitled, in relation to a financial year, to an amount at the rate of the whole or a part of twice the State average weekly earnings; and

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s91EA/c.content: the amount of State average weekly earnings Accident Compensation Act 1985 No. 10191 of 1985 71 is reduced in respect of a subsequent financial year— the person's entitlement, in respect of that subsequent financial year, is to be calculated as if the reduction had not taken effect, except for the purposes of this section.

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s91EA/2.content: If the amount of State average weekly earnings—

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s91EA/2/a.content: is reduced in respect of a financial year; and

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s91EA/2/b.content: is increased in respect of a subsequent financial year— that increase has effect in relation to a person to whom subsection (1) applies only to the extent (if any) to which the amount of the increase exceeds the amount of the reduction in respect of the previous financial year, or that part of the reduction that has not been set off against a previous increase.

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s91EA/3.content: For the purposes of this Act, if twice the State average weekly earnings is an amount that includes a fraction of a dollar, a reference in this Act to twice the State average weekly earnings is a reference to that amount calculated—

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s91EA/3/a.content: if that amount is less than $1000, to the nearest whole dollar;

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s91EA/3/b.content: if that amount is more than $1000, to the nearest $10.

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s91EA/4.content: For the purposes of this section—

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s91EA/4/a.content: a person who becomes entitled, in relation to a financial year, to an amount at the rate of the whole or a part of twice the State average weekly earnings; and inserted by No. 41/2016 s. 4.

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s91EA/b.content: in that financial year, the amount of State Accident Compensation Act 1985 No. 10191 of 1985 72 average weekly earnings is reduced in respect of the previous financial year— the person's entitlement, in respect of that financial year, is to be calculated using the amount of State average weekly earnings in the last preceding financial year in which the State average weekly earnings was not reduced.

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s92.title: Compensation for death of a worker
/au-victoria/aca/1985/s92.content:
Accident Compensation Act 1985

75   
 (7) A dependant is entitled to interest at the 
prescribed rate on an amount of compensation
