/au-victoria/aca/1985/s129M/1.content: It makes no difference for the purposes of this Division that, under the substantive law of another State—

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s129M/1/a.content: the nature of the circumstances is such that they would not have given rise to a cause of action had they occurred in that State; or

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s129M/1/b.content: the circumstances on which the claim is based do not give rise to a cause of action. inserted by No. 95/2003 s. 21.

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s129M/2.content: In this section— Accident Compensation Act 1985 No. 10191 of 1985 319 another State means a State other than the State with which the worker's employment is connected.

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s129M/3.content: Subsections (1)(a) and (2) apply even if damages resulting from the negligence or other tort are claimed in an action for breach of contract or other action.

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s129M/3/a.content: would have been payable but for a provision of the scheme that excludes the worker's right to compensation because the injury is attributable to any conduct or failure of the worker that is specified in that provision; or

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s129M/3/b.content: would have been payable if a claim for that compensation had been duly made, and (where applicable) an election to claim that compensation (instead of damages) had been duly made.

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s129M/4.content: A reference in this Division to a worker's employer includes a reference to—

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s129M/5.content: In this Division— State includes Territory. 129MB Claims to which Division applies

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s129M/2/a.content: the worker's employment is connected with Victoria; and

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s129M/2/b.content: the negligence or other tort or the breach of contract on which the claim is founded occurred in Victoria.

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s129M/4/a.content: injury and employer include anything that is within the scope of a corresponding term in the statutory workers compensation scheme of another State; and

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s129M/4/b.content: the determination of what constitutes employment or whether or not a person is the worker's employer is to be made on the basis that those concepts include anything that is within the scope of a corresponding concept in the statutory workers compensation scheme of another State. inserted by No. 95/2003 s. 21.

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s129M/a.content: a law that establishes, modifies or extinguishes a cause of action or a defence to a cause of action; and

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s129M/b.content: a law prescribing the time within which an action must be brought (including a law providing for the extension or abridgment of that time); and inserted by No. 95/2003 s. 21. inserted by No. 95/2003 s. 21. def. of a State's legislation about damages for a work related injury amended by No. 41/2006 s. 23.

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s129M/c.content: a law that provides for the limitation or Accident Compensation Act 1985 No. 10191 of 1985 318 exclusion of liability or the barring of a right of action if a proceeding on, or arbitration of, a claim is not commenced within a particular time limit; and

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s129M/d.content: a law that limits the kinds of injury, loss or damage for which damages or compensation may be recovered; and

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s129M/e.content: a law that precludes the recovery of damages or compensation or limits the amount of damages or compensation that can be recovered; and

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s129M/f.content: a law expressed as a presumption, or rule of evidence, that affects substantive rights; and

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s129M/g.content: a provision of a State's legislation about damages for a work related injury, whether or not it would be otherwise regarded as procedural in nature— but does not include a law prescribing rules for choice of law. 129MF Availability of action in another State not relevant

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s129N/1.content: In this Division— common law insurer means an insurer, other than the Authority, which is liable to indemnify a defendant in whole or in part in respect of or in relation to a common law proceeding; common law proceeding means any suit or action by a worker to recover damages in respect of an injury, disease or death arising out of or in the course of employment or due to the nature of employment but does not include a claim, demand or application for compensation under this Act; defendant means the employer against whom a common law proceeding has been brought or made (as the case may be) by a worker; worker includes a dependant of a worker. Pt 4 Div. 6B (Heading and ss 129N– 129S) inserted by No. 13/1988 s. 6. inserted by No. 13/1988 s. 6. def. of common law insurer amended by Nos 67/1992 s. 64(7)(a), 50/1994 s. 62(7), 81/1998 s. 25(6).

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s129O.title: Application of Division
/au-victoria/aca/1985/s129O.content:
(1) This Division applies to and in relation to all 
common law proceedings brought or made (as the 
case may be) after the appointed day in respect of 
which the Authority is liable to indemnify a 
defendant in whole or in part under section 134, or 
under the Accident Compensation (WorkCover 
Insurance) Act 1993 or a policy under that Act, 
in relation to an injury, disease or death caused to 
or suffered by a worker. 
 (2) A defendant or a common law insurer may enter 
into an agreement with the Authority that the 
provisions of this Division do not apply to a 
common law proceeding to which this Division 
applies and the provisions of this Division shall 
not thereafter apply to the extent that they are 
inconsistent with that agreement. 
 * * * * *

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s129O/1.content: This Division applies to and in relation to all common law proceedings brought or made (as the case may be) after the appointed day in respect of which the Authority is liable to indemnify a defendant in whole or in part under section 134, or under the Accident Compensation (WorkCover Insurance) Act 1993 or a policy under that Act, in relation to an injury, disease or death caused to or suffered by a worker.

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s129O/2.content: A defendant or a common law insurer may enter into an agreement with the Authority that the provisions of this Division do not apply to a common law proceeding to which this Division applies and the provisions of this Division shall not thereafter apply to the extent that they are inconsistent with that agreement. * * * * *

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s129P.title: Apportionment of liability
/au-victoria/aca/1985/s129P.content:
Accident Compensation Act 1985 
No. 10191 of 1985 
321   
such manner as is, and upon such terms as are, 
agreed or, in default of agreement, as are 
determined in accordance with the provisions of 
this Division by a court to be just and equitable.

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s129Q.title: Notice of proceedings
/au-victoria/aca/1985/s129Q.content:
(1) The defendant in a common law proceeding made 
or brought (as the case may be) after the appointed 
day shall give to the Authority notice in writing of 
the proceeding within 14 days after the defendant 
receives notice of the proceeding or within 
28 days after the commencement of the Accident 
Compensation (Further Amendment) Act 1988, 
whichever is the later. 
 (2) The common law insurer in respect of the 
common law proceeding shall give to the 
Authority notice in writing of the proceeding 
within 14 days after the insurer receives notice 
of the proceeding or within 28 days after the 
commencement of the Accident Compensation 
(Further Amendment) Act 1988, whichever is 
the later.

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s129Q/1.content: The defendant in a common law proceeding made or brought (as the case may be) after the appointed day shall give to the Authority notice in writing of the proceeding within 14 days after the defendant receives notice of the proceeding or within 28 days after the commencement of the Accident Compensation (Further Amendment) Act 1988, whichever is the later.

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s129Q/2.content: The common law insurer in respect of the common law proceeding shall give to the Authority notice in writing of the proceeding within 14 days after the insurer receives notice of the proceeding or within 28 days after the commencement of the Accident Compensation (Further Amendment) Act 1988, whichever is the later.

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s129R.title: Conduct of defence
/au-victoria/aca/1985/s129R.content:
Accident Compensation Act 1985 
No. 10191 of 1985 
323   
 (5) Subject to subsection (3), any person entitled to 
conduct and which conducts the defence of a 
common law proceeding in accordance with this 
section— 
 (a) is liable to make full payment of all costs and 
damages awarded or agreed to be paid to the 
worker or other person bringing or making 
(as the case may be) the common law 
proceeding; and 
 (b) is authorized by each person under any legal 
liability in respect of the injury the subject of 
the proceeding and each common law insurer 
which is liable to indemnify any such person 
in respect of or in relation to the proceeding 
to make admissions, including admissions of 
liability, and to agree to or compromise or 
settle the common law proceeding; and 
 (c) shall on behalf of the defendant adopt a 
defence which has the intention of 
minimizing the damages payable to the 
worker, regardless of whether this defence 
advantages or disadvantages the Authority, 
the defendant or the common law insurer.

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s129R/1.content: The defendant or the common law insurer is not entitled to conduct the defence of the common law proceeding unless—

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s129R/1/a.content: the defendant or common law insurer, within 14 days after the last date for giving notice under section 129Q undertakes to the Authority in writing that the defendant or common law insurer, as the case requires, will conduct the defence of the common law proceeding; and inserted by No. 13/1988 s. 6, amended by No. 67/1992 s. 64(7)(a). inserted by No. 13/1988 s. 6, amended by No. 67/1992 s. 64(7)(a).

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s129R/b.content: the Authority does not within 7 days after Accident Compensation Act 1985 No. 10191 of 1985 322 receiving the undertaking give notice in writing to the defendant or common law insurer objecting to the defendant or common law insurer conducting the defence; or

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s129R/c.content: the court in which the common law proceeding is brought at any time orders or directs that the defendant or common law insurer is entitled to conduct the defence of the common law proceeding under this section.

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s129R/2.content: If the court considers that the interest of one of the Authority, defendant or common law insurer in conducting the defence in proceedings is substantially greater than the interest of the other of the Authority, defendant or common law insurer, any order or direction under subsection (1) must be in favour of the person with the greater interest, unless the court considers it just and equitable to provide otherwise.

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s129R/3.content: Subsection (1) does not prevent the defendant or common law insurer conducting the defence of the common law proceeding in accordance with its legal entitlement to do so from the date the defendant or common law insurer received notice of the common law proceeding until the expiration of the period set out in subsection (1)(b) but in so conducting the defence, the defendant and common law insurer must not settle or compromise the common law proceeding without the consent of the Authority.

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s129R/4.content: If a defendant or common law insurer is at any time not entitled to conduct the defence of a common law proceeding in accordance with this section, the Authority or self-insurer may conduct the defence.

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s129R/5.content: Subject to subsection (3), any person entitled to Accident Compensation Act 1985 No. 10191 of 1985 323 conduct and which conducts the defence of a common law proceeding in accordance with this section—

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s129R/5/a.content: is liable to make full payment of all costs and damages awarded or agreed to be paid to the worker or other person bringing or making (as the case may be) the common law proceeding; and

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s129R/5/b.content: is authorized by each person under any legal liability in respect of the injury the subject of the proceeding and each common law insurer which is liable to indemnify any such person in respect of or in relation to the proceeding to make admissions, including admissions of liability, and to agree to or compromise or settle the common law proceeding; and

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s129R/5/c.content: shall on behalf of the defendant adopt a defence which has the intention of minimizing the damages payable to the worker, regardless of whether this defence advantages or disadvantages the Authority, the defendant or the common law insurer.

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s129S.title: Order for apportionment of liability
/au-victoria/aca/1985/s129S.content:
Accident Compensation Act 1985 
No. 10191 of 1985 
325   
 (6) An apportionment in accordance with this 
Division is an apportionment in relation to the 
amount of damages and costs awarded or agreed 
to be paid in accordance with this Division and of 
the costs of the conduct of the defence of the 
common law proceedings.

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s129S/1.content: In default of agreement under section 129P, the Authority, the defendant and any common law insurer may at any time before entry of judgment in a common law proceeding, apply to the court in which the common law proceeding is brought for orders apportioning liability in respect of all damages and costs recovered or recoverable in the common law proceeding in accordance with that section, including orders in respect of the payment of all amounts required to be paid as a consequence of any such apportionment. inserted by No. 13/1988 s. 6, amended by No. 67/1992 s. 64(7)(a).

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s129S/2.content: The court to which application is made under Accident Compensation Act 1985 No. 10191 of 1985 324 subsection (1)—

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s129S/2/a.content: may give such directions in relation to interlocutory orders for discovery, inspection and better particulars and for the filing of pleadings as it deems appropriate; and

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s129S/2/b.content: shall hear and determine the application for apportionment in such manner and at such time as it deems appropriate.

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s129S/3.content: If an application is not made under subsection (1), the Authority, the defendant and any common law insurer may apply to any court of competent jurisdiction for orders apportioning liability in respect of all damages and costs recovered or recoverable in a common law proceeding in accordance with section 129P, including orders in respect of the payment of all amounts required to be paid as a consequence of any such apportionment.

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s129S/4.content: The court to which application is brought under subsection (3)—

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s129S/4/a.content: may give such directions in relation to interlocutory orders for discovery, inspection and better particulars and for the filing of pleadings as it deems appropriate; and

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s129S/4/b.content: shall hear and determine the claim for apportionment in such manner and at such time as it deems appropriate.

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s129S/5.content: An application to a court under subsection (3) shall be made within 12 months after the commencement of the Accident Compensation (Further Amendment) Act 1988 or within 12 months of the person making the application receiving notice of the entry of judgment, settlement or compromise of the common law proceeding, whichever is the later.

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s129S/6.content: An apportionment in accordance with this Accident Compensation Act 1985 No. 10191 of 1985 325 Division is an apportionment in relation to the amount of damages and costs awarded or agreed to be paid in accordance with this Division and of the costs of the conduct of the defence of the common law proceedings.

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s130.title: Certain funds to be administered by trustee
/au-victoria/aca/1985/s130.content:
Accident Compensation Act 1985 
No. 10191 of 1985 
326   
 (1A) If the Court or Authority determines under 
subsection (1) that State Trustees (within the 
meaning of the State Trustees (State Owned 
Company) Act 1994) administer payments of 
compensation, State Trustees must accept a 
transfer of the amount of compensation to be 
administered and the acceptance of that amount is 
a sufficient discharge to the person transferring 
that amount. 
 (2) The County Court in making a determination on 
an application under subsection (1)(c) may impose 
any conditions, restrictions or limitations it 
considers appropriate on the duration and 
termination of the administration.

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s130/1.content: The following payments of compensation shall be company25 paid to a trustee company determined by the Court or the Authority (as the case requires) to be administered by the trustee company in accordance with this Act—

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s130/1/a.content: any payment under section 92, 98 or 98A to a person under the age of 18 years;

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s130/1/b.content: unless the County Court otherwise determines, any payment under section 92 to a person of or over the age of 18 years; and

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s130/1/c.content: any other payment of compensation under this Act where on an application to the County Court the County Court considers it would be in the best interests of the worker. Pt 4 Div. 7 (Heading) amended by Nos 64/1989 s. 37(1)(c), 67/1992 s. 45(a), 50/1994 s. 63(1)(a), 74/2000 s. 3(Sch. 1 item 1.5). amended by Nos 83/1987 s. 72(1)(a), 67/1992 s. 45(a), 50/1994 s. 63(1)(b), 15/1998 s. 4(1)(a)(b). amended by Nos 83/1987 s. 72(1)(b), 50/1993 s. 110(1)(f). amended by No. 67/1992 s. 45(b). amended by No. 67/1992 s. 45(b).

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s130/2.content: The County Court in making a determination on Accident Compensation Act 1985 No. 10191 of 1985 326 (1A) If the Court or Authority determines under subsection (1) that State Trustees (within the meaning of the State Trustees (State Owned Company) Act 1994) administer payments of compensation, State Trustees must accept a transfer of the amount of compensation to be administered and the acceptance of that amount is a sufficient discharge to the person transferring that amount. an application under subsection (1)(c) may impose any conditions, restrictions or limitations it considers appropriate on the duration and termination of the administration.

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s131.title: Powers of trustee company in relation to

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s131/1.content: Except as otherwise provided in section 130, administration any money administered by a trustee company determined under that section may be invested in any manner in which money may be invested under the Trustee Act 1958 and may be applied in any manner that the trustee company considers appropriate for the benefit of the person entitled to that money. * * * * * inserted by No. 15/1998 s. 4(2). amended by Nos 83/1987 s. 72(1)(c), 67/1992 s. 45(b). amended by Nos 83/1987 s. 72(2)(a), 67/1992 s. 45(a), 50/1994 s. 63(1)(b), substituted by No. 15/1998 s. 4(3). amended by Nos 83/1987 s. 72(2)(a), 67/1992 s. 45(a), 50/1994 s. 63(1)(b), repealed by No. 15/1998 s. 4(4).

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s131/4.content: If the amount of money administered on behalf of Accident Compensation Act 1985 No. 10191 of 1985 327 * * * * * any person by a trustee company determined under section 130 becomes less than an amount determined by the trustee company, the amount shall be paid out by the trustee company to that person.

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s131/5.content: A trustee company must, within a reasonable period of time before paying out an amount under subsection (4), give written notice to the person entitled to the money of its intention to pay out that amount.

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s131/6.content: A person entitled to money under this section who objects to a determination of the trustee company made under subsection (4) may appeal to the County Court and the Court may make a new determination. substituted by No. 83/1987 s. 72(2)(b), amended by Nos 67/1992 s. 45(b), 50/1993 s. 110(1)(g), repealed by No. 50/1994 s. 63(1)(c). amended by Nos 83/1987 s. 72(2)(c)(i)(ii), 67/1992 s. 45(a), 50/1994 s. 63(1)(b), substituted by No. 15/1998 s. 4(5). substituted by No. 83/1987 s. 72(2)(d), amended by Nos 64/1989 s. 35(h), 67/1992 s. 45(a)(c), 50/1993 s. 110(1)(h), repealed by No. 50/1994 s. 63(1)(c), new s. 131(5) inserted by No. 15/1998 s. 4(5). repealed by No. 83/1987 s. 72(2)(e), new s. 131(6) inserted by No. 15/1998 s. 4(5).

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s132.title: Powers of trustee company to make determinations

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s132/2.content: Before a litigated claims legal costs order is made under subsection (1), the Minister must consult with the Attorney-General and Treasurer. inserted by No. 80/2010 s. 96.

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s132/2/a.content: must be published in the Government Gazette;

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s132/2/b.content: takes effect on and from the date on which it is published or any later date of commencement as may be specified in the order;

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s132/2/c.content: applies to legal costs incurred on or after the date of commencement of the order.

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s132/3.content: A litigated claims legal costs order— Accident Compensation Act 1985 No. 10191 of 1985 364

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s132/5.content: If a litigated claims legal costs order under subsection (1)(a) is in force, legal costs in respect of any claim, application or proceeding referred to in subsection (1)(a) to which the order applies cannot be recovered except in accordance with the order.

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s132/a.content: permanent serious impairment or loss Accident Compensation Act 1985 No. 10191 of 1985 350 response date means the date on which the period of 28 days after the determination date expires; serious injury means— of a body function; or

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s132/b.content: prescribing or specifying any matter or thing Accident Compensation Act 1985 No. 10191 of 1985 362 required to give effect to the legal costs order including procedures for resolving any dispute that arises in relation to the costs payable under the order.

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s132/1.content: Subject to subsection (2), the Governor in Council may by Order in Council make a litigated claims legal costs order—

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s132/1/a.content: specifying the legal costs that may be recovered from a worker by a legal practitioner acting on behalf of the Authority or self-insurer in respect of any claim, application or proceedings under or in accordance with section 134AB, 135, 135A or 135B; and

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s132/3/a.content: must be published in the Government Gazette;

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s132/3/b.content: takes effect on and from the date on which it is published or any later date of commencement as may be specified in the order;

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s132/4.content: Section 134AB(29), 135A(13B) or 135B(7) does not apply in proceedings to which a litigated claims legal costs order under subsection (1)(a) applies.

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s132/4/a.content: the degree of impairment resulting from the injury has been determined in accordance with section 104B; and

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s132/4/b.content: the worker has accepted the determination of the degree of impairment; and substituted by No. 102/2004 s. 6(1), amended by No. 80/2010 s. 64(1)(b). (4)(a)(i) amended by No. 41/2006 s. 24(a). (4)(b)(ii) amended by No. 41/2006 s. 24(b). inserted by No. 80/2010 s. 64(2).

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s132/c.content: any right arising from a determination by a Court, the Authority or a self-insurer that a worker had a serious injury is deemed, for the purposes of section 29 of the Administration and Probate Act 1958 to have vested in the worker before the worker's death and survives for the benefit of the deceased worker's estate.

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s132/5/a.content: pain and suffering damages in respect of the injury; and

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s132/5/b.content: if the deceased worker's application established the matters specified in section 134AB(38)(e), (f) and (g)— pecuniary loss damages in respect of the injury— from the date the injury was sustained to the date of death of the worker.

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s132/5/c.content: be accompanied by— (i) a copy of all medical reports; and (ii) affidavits attesting to other material— existing when the application is made and of which the worker or his or her legal representative is aware and on which the worker intends to rely, or the substance of which the worker intends to adduce in evidence, in proceedings in accordance with this section or in any related proceedings. (5AA) An authority to release information referred to in subsection (5)(b) has effect and cannot be revoked by the worker—

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s132/6.content: If a litigated claims legal costs order under subsection (1) is in force, legal costs in respect of any claim, application or proceeding referred to in subsection (1) to which the order applies cannot be recovered except in accordance with the order. 134AGB Litigated claims legal costs order—Authority and self-insurers

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s132/7.content: The death of a worker does not affect the admissibility of—

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s132/7/a.content: evidence obtained before or after the worker served an application under section 134AB(4); and

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s132/7/b.content: evidence that would have otherwise been admissible under section 134AB.

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s132/8.content: In this section— Accident Compensation Act 1985 No. 10191 of 1985 357 dependant means a person who at the time of the death of the worker referred to in subsection (1)—

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s132/8/a.content: was wholly, mainly or partly dependent on the earnings of the worker; or

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s132/8/b.content: would have been wholly, mainly or partly dependent on the earnings of the worker but for the incapacity of the worker resulting from, or materially contributed to by, the serious injury the subject of the application, or any incapacity of the worker due to the injury or disease which caused or materially contributed to the worker's death.

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s132/9.content: A reference to service of an application under section 134AB(4) in this section means the service of an application in accordance with directions made by the Minister under section 134AF. 134ABA Calculation of limitation of actions period For the purpose of calculating the period of time under the Limitation of Actions Act 1958 within which proceedings permitted by, and in accordance with, section 134AB may be commenced on or after the commencement of section 9 of the Accident Compensation Legislation (Amendment) Act 2004, the following periods of time are to be disregarded—

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s132/10.content: The worker, within 28 days after receiving the Accident Compensation Act 1985 No. 10191 of 1985 336 worker is deemed to have suffered a serious injury. advice referred to in subsections (7) and (8), may give to the Authority or self-insurer an affidavit attesting to such further material (whether or not existing before the worker made the application under subsection (4)) in rebuttal of the material (other than medical reports) attested to in affidavits accompanying the advice.

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s132/11.content: In proceedings in accordance with this section, a medical report or other material is inadmissible in evidence—

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s132/11/a.content: on behalf of the Authority or self-insurer if— (i) it was in existence, and the employer, Authority or self-insurer, or the legal representative or any of them, was aware of it, before the date by which the advice of the Authority or self- insurer is required to be given under subsections (7) and (8); and (ii) it had not been disclosed to the worker in accordance with subsections (7) and (8); or

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s132/11/b.content: on behalf of the worker if— (i) it was in existence, and the worker or the worker's legal representative was aware of it, before the expiration of 28 days after receiving the advice under subsections (7) and (8); and (ii) it had not been disclosed to the other party in accordance with subsection (5) or (10).

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s132/12.content: The worker must not commence proceedings in Accident Compensation Act 1985 No. 10191 of 1985 337 accordance with this section, other than an application under subsection (16)(b) or the commencement of proceedings with the consent of the Authority under subsection (20) or (20A), unless—

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s132/12/a.content: the worker and the Authority or self-insurer hold, or begin, a conference within 21 days after the response date; and

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s132/12/b.content: the Authority or self-insurer makes a statutory offer in writing in settlement or compromise of the claim at that conference, or after the conference begins but no later than 60 days after the response date; and

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s132/12/c.content: if the worker does not accept that statutory offer within 21 days after it is made, the worker, before the expiration of that period, makes a statutory counter offer in writing in settlement or compromise of the claim; and

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s132/12/d.content: the Authority or self-insurer does not accept that counter offer within 21 days after it is made; and

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s132/12/e.content: the proceedings are commenced not earlier than 21 days, and not more than 51 days, after the counter offer is made or, if a counter offer is deemed to have been made under subsection (14), not more than 30 days after the day on which the counter offer is deemed to have been made.

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s132/13.content: If the Authority or self-insurer does not make a statutory offer under subsection (12), the Authority or self-insurer is deemed, for the purposes of that subsection, to have made, on the 60th day after the response date, a statutory offer of nothing. amended by No. 82/2001 s. 22(1)(a).

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s132/14.content: If the Authority or self-insurer makes a statutory Accident Compensation Act 1985 No. 10191 of 1985 338 offer under subsection (12) and the worker does not make a statutory counter offer under that subsection, the worker is deemed, for the purposes of that subsection, to have made, on the 21st day after the statutory offer was made, a statutory counter offer of the maximum amount that may be awarded as damages under subsection (22)(a) and (b).

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s132/15.content: If the assessment under section 104B made before an application under subsection (4) is made of the degree of impairment of the worker as a result of the injury is 30 per centum or more, the injury is deemed to be a serious injury within the meaning of this section.

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s132/16.content: If the assessment under section 104B of the degree of impairment of the worker as a result of the injury is less than 30 per centum, the person may not bring proceedings for the recovery of damages in respect of the injury unless—

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s132/16/a.content: the Authority or self-insurer— (i) is satisfied that the injury is a serious injury; and (ii) issues to the worker a certificate in writing consenting to the bringing of the proceedings; or

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s132/16/b.content: a court, other than the Magistrates' Court, on the application of the worker made within 30 days after the worker received advice under subsection (7) or, with the consent of the Authority under subsection (20), after that period, gives leave to bring the proceedings.

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s132/17.content: For the purposes of paragraphs (a) and (b) of subsection (16), a worker who satisfies subparagraph (i) of subsection (38)(b) but not amended by No. 102/2004 s. 6(2).

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s132/18.content: A copy of an application under subsection (16) Accident Compensation Act 1985 No. 10191 of 1985 339 subparagraph (ii) of that subsection, is entitled to bring proceedings in accordance with subsection (16)(b) for the recovery of damages for pain and suffering only. must be served on the Authority or self-insurer and on each person against whom the applicant claims to have a cause of action.

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s132/19/a.content: a court, other than the Magistrates' Court, must not give leave unless it is satisfied on the balance of probabilities that the injury is a serious injury;

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s132/19/b.content: for the purposes of proving a loss of earning capacity in accordance with subsection (38), a worker bears the onus of proving any inability to be retrained or rehabilitated or to undertake suitable employment or any employment including alternative or further or additional employment and the extent of such inability; * * * * * (19A) Any finding made on an application for leave to bring proceedings in respect of the injury does not give rise to an issue estoppel in any proceedings for the recovery of damages brought in accordance with this section which is heard and determined on and from the commencement of section 57(3) of the Accident Compensation Amendment Act 2010. repealed by No. 9/2010 s. 57(2). inserted by No. 9/2010 s. 57(3).

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s132/20.content: If, on the application of a worker, the Authority is Accident Compensation Act 1985 No. 10191 of 1985 340 satisfied that—

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s132/20/a.content: either— (i) earlier than 21 days after the date the counter offer is made; or (ii) later than 51 days, but no later than 81 days, after that date— if the Authority is satisfied that the defence of the proceedings will not be prejudiced; or

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s132/20/b.content: later than 81 days after the date the counter offer is made if the Authority is satisfied that the failure to comply with subsection (12) was not due to any fault or omission of the worker or the worker's legal representative. (20B) The Authority may consent to the commencement of proceedings under subsection (20A) even though the relevant time limit expired before the amended by No. 82/2001 s. 22(1)(b)(ii). (20)(a) amended by No. 82/2001 s. 22(1)(b)(i). (20)(b) amended by No. 82/2001 s. 22(1)(b)(i). inserted by No. 82/2001 s. 22(2). inserted by No. 82/2001 s. 22(2).

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s132/21.content: If a worker makes an application under Accident Compensation Act 1985 No. 10191 of 1985 341 date of commencement of section 22 of the Accident Compensation (Amendment) Act 2001. subsection (4) in respect of an injury the worker must not make a further application under that subsection in respect of that injury. (21A) If after a worker has failed to satisfy a court that the relevant injury is a serious injury on an application for leave to bring proceedings in accordance with subsection (16)(b), the worker obtains under section 104B determinations that the degree of impairment of the worker is 30 percentum or more, the worker is not entitled to recover damages for the same relevant injury.

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s132/22.content: A court must not, in proceedings in accordance with this section, award to a worker in respect of an injury—

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s132/22/a.content: pecuniary loss damages— (i) if the total pecuniary loss damages assessed, before the reduction (if any) under section 26(1) of the Wrongs Act 1958 and before the reduction (if any) under subsection (25), is less than $56 650 or that amount as varied in accordance with Division 2D of Part IV as at the date of the award; or (ii) in excess of $1 275 570 or that amount as varied in accordance with Division 2D of Part IV as at the date of the award; or substituted by No. 9/2010 s. 57(4). inserted by No. 102/2004 s. 6(3). (a)(i) amended by Nos 102/2004 s. 40(e), 80/2010 ss 81(b), 83(d), 67/2013 s. 633(d). (a)(ii) amended by Nos 102/2004 s. 40(f), 80/2010 ss 81(b), 83(e), 67/2013 s. 633(e).

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s132/23.content: In the trial of a proceeding brought under this section, a jury must not be informed—

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s132/23/a.content: of the monetary thresholds and statutory maximums specified by or under subsection (22); or

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s132/23/b.content: that any injury in respect of which the proceeding has been brought has been deemed, found, or required to be found, to be a serious injury; or

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s132/23/c.content: that the Authority or self-insurer has been satisfied that the injury is a serious injury; or

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s132/23/d.content: that the Authority or self-insurer has issued a certificate under subsection (16)(a).

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s132/24.content: Damages awarded under this section in respect of pecuniary loss shall not include damages in respect of— (b)(i) amended by Nos 102/2004 s. 40(g), 80/2010 ss 81(c), 83(f), 67/2013 s. 633(f). (b)(ii) amended by Nos 102/2004 s. 40(h), 9/2010 s. 55, 80/2010 s. 81(c), 83(g), 67/2013 s. 633(g).

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s132/25.content: If a judgment, order for damages, settlement or compromise is made or entered in favour of a worker or the dependants of a worker in respect of proceedings referred to in subsection (1), the amount of the judgment, order for damages, settlement or compromise must be reduced by—

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s132/25/a.content: to the extent that it is in respect of pecuniary loss, the amount of compensation (if any) paid otherwise than under section 98C, 98E and Division 2B of Part IV or to the extent that section 93(10)(a) of the Transport Accident Act 1986 applies, except any such compensation paid in respect of the whole or any part of the period of 18 months after the relevant transport accident;

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s132/25/b.content: to the extent that it is in respect of non-pecuniary loss, the amount of compensation (if any) paid under section 98C and 98E.

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s132/26.content: If the amount of a judgment is subject to a reduction under subsection (25), that reduction must be made before the reduction (if any) under section 26(1) of the Wrongs Act 1958 is made. (24)(a) amended by No. 80/2010 s. 78(q). S. 134AB(25)(a) amended by No. 48/2017 s. 5.

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s132/27.content: Subject to the rules of the court— Accident Compensation Act 1985 No. 10191 of 1985 344

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s132/27/a.content: in proceedings relating to an application for leave of the court under subsection (16), costs are to be awarded against a party against whom a decision is made; and

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s132/27/b.content: unless subsection (28) applies in proceedings for the recovery of damages in accordance with this section— (i) if no liability to pay damages is established, costs are to be awarded against the claimant; and (ii) if damages are assessed but cannot be awarded under this section, each party bears its own costs; and (iii) if damages are awarded, costs are to be awarded against the Authority or self-insurer.

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s132/28.content: In proceedings for the recovery of damages commenced in accordance with this section after a statutory offer was made, or deemed to have been made, under subsection (12)—

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s132/28/a.content: if no liability to pay damages is established, the worker must pay the costs assessed on the standard basis of the employer, Authority or self-insurer and the worker's own costs;

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s132/28/b.content: if judgment is obtained or a settlement or compromise is made in an amount not less than 90 per cent of the worker's statutory counter offer under subsection (12) and more than the statutory offer of the Authority or self-insurer, the Authority or self-insurer must pay the worker's costs assessed on the standard basis and its own costs; (28)(a) amended by No. 10/2022 s. 12(2). (28)(b) amended by No. 10/2022 s. 12(2).

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s132/d.content: apply, adopt or incorporate (with or without Accident Compensation Act 1985 No. 10191 of 1985 361 modification) the provisions of any document, code, standard, rule, specification or method whether as formulated, issued, prescribed or published at the time the order is made;

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s132/29.content: For the purpose of the taxing of costs in proceedings to which this section applies, any applicable scale of costs has effect as if amounts in the scale were reduced by 20 per cent. (28)(c) amended by No. 10/2022 s. 12(2). inserted by No. 9/2010 s. 57(5). inserted by No. 9/2010 s. 57(5).

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s132/30.content: A person who represents or acts on behalf of a Accident Compensation Act 1985 No. 10191 of 1985 346 worker is not entitled—

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s132/30/a.content: to recover any costs from that worker in respect of any proceedings under this section; or

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s132/30/b.content: to claim a lien in respect of those costs; or

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s132/30/c.content: to deduct those costs from any sum awarded as damages— unless an award of costs has been made by the court in respect of those costs or those costs are payable in accordance with this section by the worker.

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s132/31.content: The court, on the application of—

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s132/31/b.content: the person representing or acting on behalf of the worker— may determine the amount of costs to be awarded to the person representing or acting on behalf of the worker.

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s132/32.content: Where an award of damages in accordance with this section is to include an amount, assessed as a lump sum, in respect of damages for future loss which is referable to—

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s132/32/a.content: deprivation or impairment of earning capacity; or

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s132/32/b.content: loss of the expectation of financial support; or

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s132/32/c.content: a liability to incur expenditure in the future; or

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s132/32/d.content: any loss suffered by a dependant— the present value of the future loss must be qualified by adopting a discount rate of 6 per centum in order to make appropriate allowance for

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s132/33.content: Except as provided by subsection (32), nothing in Accident Compensation Act 1985 No. 10191 of 1985 347 inflation, the income from investment of the sum awarded and the effect of taxation on that income. that subsection affects any other law relating to the discounting of sums awarded as damages.

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s132/34.content: A court must not, in relation to an award of damages in accordance with this section, order the payment of interest, and no interest shall be payable, on any amount of damages, other than damages referable to loss actually suffered before the date of the award, in respect of the period from the date of the death of or injury to the person in respect of whom the award is made to date of the award.

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s132/35.content: Except as provided by subsection (34), nothing in that subsection affects any other law relating to the payment of interest on any amount of damages, other than special damages.

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s132/36.content: If judgment is obtained, or a compromise or settlement made in respect of proceedings referred to in subsection (1) in respect of an injury, the Authority, the employer or self-insurer is not liable—

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s132/36/a.content: where pecuniary loss damages are awarded, to pay weekly payments in respect of the injury; or

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s132/36/b.content: where pain and suffering damages are awarded, to make payments under section 98C or 98E in respect of the injury. (36A) If judgment is obtained, or a compromise or a settlement is made, in respect of proceedings referred to in subsection (1) and the worker was, at the date of the judgment, compromise or (36)(a) amended by Nos 41/2006 s. 15(4), 9/2010 s. 57(6). inserted by No. 9/2010 s. 57(7).

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s132/37.content: In this section— Accident Compensation Act 1985 No. 10191 of 1985 348 settlement, still in receipt of compensation in the form of weekly payments, where pecuniary loss damages are awarded against the Authority, employer or self-insurer, the Authority, employer or self-insurer must, until the date on which a cheque is drawn for the purpose of payment of the judgment, compromise or settlement, pay to the worker a weekly amount equal to the net weekly amount that, but for subsection (36), would have been payable to the worker as compensation in the form of weekly payments in respect of the injury. (36B) Subsection (36A) applies only in respect of proceedings referred to in subsection (1) against a sole defendant where that sole defendant was the worker's employer at the date of the injury the subject of the proceedings. (36C) An amount paid in accordance with subsection (36A) is, to the extent of the payment, part satisfaction of the liability in respect of the judgment, settlement or compromise. determination date, in relation to an injury, means the date on which—

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s132/37/a.content: if the worker is assessed under section 104B to have a degree of impairment of 30 per centum or more, the date on which the worker receives advice under subsection (7); or

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s132/37/ab.content: if the Authority or self-insurer fails to advise the worker in writing as required by subsection (7) within the period referred to in subsection (7), the date on which under subsection (9) the injury is deemed to be a serious injury; or inserted by No. 9/2010 s. 57(7). inserted by No. 9/2010 s. 57(7). def. of determination date amended by No. 102/2004 s. 8(1)(2).

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s132/38.content: For the purposes of the assessment of serious injury in accordance with subsections (16) and (19)—

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s132/38/a.content: the following definitions apply— foetus has the same meaning as in section 98C(5); income from personal exertion has the same meaning as in section 6(2) of the Transport Accident Act 1986;

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s132/38/b.content: the terms serious and severe are to be satisfied by reference to the consequences to the worker of any impairment or loss of a body function, disfigurement, or mental or behavioural disturbance or disorder, as the case may be, with respect to— (i) pain and suffering; or (ii) loss of earning capacity— when judged by comparison with other cases in the range of possible impairments or losses of a body function, disfigurements, or mental or behavioural disturbances or disorders, respectively;

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s132/e.content: authorise any specified person or body to determine or apply a specified matter or thing.

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s132/f.content: for the purposes of paragraph (e)(i), a Accident Compensation Act 1985 No. 10191 of 1985 352 (i) at the date of a decision under subsection (16)(a) or at the date of the hearing of an application under subsection (16)(b), the worker has a loss of earning capacity of 40 per centum or more, measured (except in the case of a worker referred to in item 1 of Schedule 1A or a worker under the age of 26 years at the date of the injury) as set out in paragraph (f); and (ii) the worker (including a worker referred to in item 1 of Schedule 1A or a worker under the age of 26 years at the date of the injury) will after the date of the decision or of the hearing continue permanently to have a loss of earning capacity which will be productive of financial loss of 40 per centum or more; worker's loss of earning capacity is to be measured by comparing— (i) the worker's gross income from personal exertion (expressed at an annual rate) which the worker is— (A) earning, whether in suitable employment or not; or (B) capable of earning in suitable employment— as at that date, whichever is the greater, and— (ii) the gross income (expressed at an annual rate) that the worker was earning or was capable of earning from personal exertion or would have earned or would have been capable of earning (38)(e)(i) amended by No. 67/2013 s. 638(4) (as amended by No. 44/2014 s. 24(32)). (38)(e)(ii) amended by No. 67/2013 s. 638(4) (as amended by No. 44/2014 s. 24(32)). (38)(f) substituted by No. 9/2010 s. 57(8)(a).

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s132/g.content: a worker does not establish the loss of Accident Compensation Act 1985 No. 10191 of 1985 353 from personal exertion during that part of the period within 3 years before and 3 years after the injury as most fairly reflects the worker's earning capacity had the injury not occurred; earning capacity required by paragraph (b) where the worker has, or would have after rehabilitation or retraining, and taking into account the worker's capacity for suitable employment after the injury and, where applicable, the reasonableness of the worker's attempts to participate in rehabilitation or retraining, a capacity for any employment including alternative employment or further or additional employment which, if exercised, would result in the worker earning more than 60 per centum of gross income from personal exertion as determined in accordance with paragraph (f) had the injury not occurred;

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s132/h.content: the psychological or psychiatric consequences of a physical injury are to be taken into account only for the purposes of paragraph (c) of the definition of serious injury and not otherwise; (i) the physical consequences of a mental or behavioural disturbance or disorder are to be taken into account only for the purposes of paragraph (c) of the definition of serious injury and not otherwise;

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s132/j.content: the assessment of serious injury shall be made at the time that the application is heard by the court, unless sections 134ABAA and 135BBA apply; (38)(j) amended by No. 9/2010 s. 57(8)(b).

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s132/k.content: the monetary thresholds and statutory Accident Compensation Act 1985 No. 10191 of 1985 354 maximums specified by or under subsection (22) must be disregarded for the purposes of the assessment of serious injury. 134ABAA Determination of serious injury application following death of worker

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s132/1/b.content: prescribing or specifying any matter or thing required to give effect to the legal costs order including procedures for resolving any dispute that arises in relation to the costs payable under the Order.

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s132/1/c.content: at the time of the worker's death— (i) the application of the worker was pending; or (ii) the worker had issued proceedings seeking the leave of the Court to commence proceedings following the rejection of the application of the worker by the Authority or a self-insurer; or (iii) the period specified in section 134AB(16)(b) within which a worker is required to institute proceedings had not expired; and

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s132/1/d.content: the worker's death was not caused or materially contributed to by the injury which is the subject of the application under section 134AB; and

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s132/1/e.content: the worker left a dependant or dependants.

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s132/6/a.content: section 134AB(38)(e) applies as if a reference to "the date of the hearing of an application" were a reference to the date on which the application under section 134AB(4) was served;

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s132/6/b.content: section 134AB(38)(f) applies as if a reference to "that date" were a reference to the date on which the application under section 134AB(4) was served.

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s132/9/a.content: if the degree of permanent impairment of the worker resulting from the injury is to be determined, the period of time commencing on the day a claim for compensation under section 98C or 98E is lodged and ending 30 days after— inserted by No. 102/2004 s. 9. amended by No. 80/2010 s. 93.

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s132/3/c.content: applies to legal costs incurred on or after the date of commencement of the order;

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s132/3/d.content: in the case of— (i) the first litigated legal costs order to be made under subsection (1) after the commencement of section 99 of the Transport Accident and Accident Compensation Legislation Amendment Act 2010, must be reviewed by the Minister within 2 years of the commencement of the litigated legal costs order; (ii) each subsequent litigated legal costs order made under subsection (1) after the litigated legal costs order specified in subparagraph (i) is made, must be reviewed by the Minister 3 years after commencement of each subsequent litigated legal costs order.

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s134A.title: Actions for damages only in accordance with this

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s134A/1.content: A worker who is, or the dependants of a worker Act who are or may be, entitled to compensation in respect of an injury arising out of or in the course of, or due to the nature of, employment on or after 12 November 1997 but before 20 October 1999 shall not, in proceedings commenced in respect of the injury or otherwise, recover any damages of any kind.

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s134A/2.content: Subsection (1) does not prevent the recovery of damages in proceedings under Part III of the Wrongs Act 1958, subject to and in accordance with the Transport Accident Act 1986, in respect of the death of a worker—

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s134A/2/a.content: arising out of a transport accident within the meaning of the Transport Accident Act 1986; and

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s134A/2/b.content: arising out of, or in the course of, or due to the nature of, any employment that was a significant contributing factor resulting in or materially contributing to the death. Pt 4 Div. 9 (Heading) substituted by No. 26/2000 s. 20(2). inserted by No. 107/1997 s. 45. amended by No. 26/2000 s. 21.

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s135/2.content: For the purposes of proceedings to which * * * * * * * * * * subsection (1) (as in force at any time) or section 134A(2) applies, sections 135(1A) to (7) and 135A, and any other relevant provisions, of this Act as in force immediately before the commencement of section 46 of the Accident Compensation (WorkCover) Act 1992 continue to apply as if they had not been repealed by that Act. amended by Nos 111/1986 s. 180(3)(Sch. 2 item 3(b)(i)), 83/1987 s. 74(a), 67/1992 s. 46(1), 50/1994 s. 64(1)–(4), repealed by No. 107/1997 s. 46(1). inserted by No. 111/1986 s. 180(3) (Sch. 2 item 3(b)(ii)), amended by No. 83/1987 s. 74(a), repealed by No. 67/1992 s. 46(2). amended by No. 83/1987 s. 74(a), substituted by No. 67/1992 s. 46(2), amended by No. 107/1997 s. 46(2).

/au-victoria/aca/1985/s135/3.content: Subsection (1), as in force immediately before Accident Compensation Act 1985 No. 10191 of 1985 367 12 November 1997, continues to apply, subject to section 135AC, in respect of an injury arising out of, or in the course of, or due to the nature of, employment before that commencement. * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * amended by Nos 48/1986 s. 23, 111/1986 s. 180(3) (Sch. 2 item 3(b)(iii)), 83/1987 s. 74(b), repealed by No. 67/1992 s. 46(2), new s. 135(3) inserted by No. 107/1997 s. 46(3). inserted by No. 83/1987 s. 74(c), amended by No. 18/1991 s. 10(2), repealed by No. 67/1992 s. 46(2). inserted by No. 83/1987 s. 74(c), repealed by No. 67/1992 s. 46(2). amended by Nos 48/1986 s. 23, 83/1987 s. 74(d), 64/1989 s. 35(i), repealed by No. 67/1992 s. 46(2). inserted by No. 83/1987 s. 74(e), repealed by No. 67/1992 s. 46(2).
